column42: and that reënforcements of men and other things should be sent him. It was learned that he intended to make an ill use of the government
column43: and would not remain dependent on
column44: and subordinate to
column45: the governor of the Filipinas; and that he was depriving the heirs of Estevan Rodriguez of what lawfully belonged to them. It was learned that
column46: in order to make himself safer in this respect
column47: he was sending his confidants to the town of Arevalo in Oton where Don Estevan had left his wife
column48: Doña Ana de Osseguera
column49: and his two small daughters
column50: with his house and property
column51: to persuade Doña Ana to marry him. This resolution appeared injurious in many respects
column52: and the attempt was made to rectify matters. But in order not to disturb the affairs of Mindanao
column53: the matter was left alone for the present
column54: until time should show the course to be followed. And so it happened that when Juan de la Xara left the camp and settlements of Mindanao
column55: and came hurriedly to Oton to negotiate his marriage in person--although the widow of Don Estevan had never been favorable to it--Don Francisco Tello sent men to arrest him. He was brought to Manila
column56: where he died while his trial was being conducted.After the imprisonment of Juan de La Xara
column57: Don Francisco Tello immediately sent Captain Toribio de Miranda to Mindanao
column58: with orders to take command of the camp and to govern
column59: until some one should agree to continue the enterprise. When he arrived at Mindanao and the soldiers saw that Juan de La Xara's schemes had been defeated
column60: and that the latter was a prisoner in Manila
column61: with no hope of returning
column62: they obeyed Toribio de Miranda and the orders that he brought.In Manila the governor was considering carefully the necessary measures for continuing the war
column63: since the island of Mindanao was so near the other pacified islands
column64: and the island itself contained some provinces that professed peace and were apportioned as encomiendas
column65: and had Spanish magistrates
column66: such as the rivers of Butuan
column67: Dapitan
column68: and Caragan
column69: so that it was desirable to pacify the whole island and subject it to his Majesty. The royal treasury was spent and could not bear the expense; and Estevan Rodriguez had bound himself by a legal writ
column70: to carry the war to entire completion at his own expense
column71: in accordance with the terms of his agreement. The guardian of his children and heirs brought the matter before the court
column72: and refused to fulfil this obligation on account of Estevan Rodriguez's death. In order not to lose time
column73: for what had been commenced had to be continued in one way or another
column74: the governor decided to prosecute it
column75: drawing the necessary funds from the royal treasury
column76: either on its own account or on the account of Estevan Rodriguez's heirs
column77: if such should be according to law. The governor then searched for a person to go to Mindanao
column78: and selected Don Juan Ronquillo
column79: general of the galleys. The latter was given the necessary reënforcements of men and other things
column80: with which he reached Mindanao. He took command of the Spanish camp and fleet which he found in Tampacan. He confirmed the peace and friendship with the chiefs and people of Tampacan and Lumaguan
column81: restored and set in better order the Spanish settlement and fort
column82: and began to make preparation for the war against the people of Buhahayen. He spent many days in making a few incursions into their land and attacks on their forts
column84: for the enemy were many and all good soldiers
column85: with plenty of arquebuses [63] and artillery
column86: and had fortified themselves in a strong position. They had many other fortifications inland and went from one to the other with impunity
column89: who were little used to so swampy a country. The latter found themselves short of provisions without the possibility of getting them in the country on account of the war
column90: inasmuch as the camp contained many men
column91: both Spaniards and the native servants and boatmen
column92: and it was not easy at all times to come and go from one part to another in order to provide necessities. [64]

column1: Meanwhile Don Juan Ronquillo
column2: seeing that the war was advancing very slowly and with little result
column3: and that the camp was suffering
column4: drew up a report of it
column5: and sent letters in all haste to Governor Don Francisco Tello
column6: informing him of the condition of affairs. He wrote that it would be better to withdraw the camp from Mindanao River
column7: so that it might not perish; and that a presidio could be established on the same island in the port of La Caldera
column8: which could be left fortified
column9: in order not to abandon this enterprise entirely
column10: and so that their friends of Tampacan and Lumaguan might be kept hostile to the people of Buhahayen. Meanwhile he and the rest of the camp and fleet would return to Manila
column11: if permitted
column12: for which he requested the governor to send him an order quickly. Upon the receipt of this despatch
column13: Governor Don Francisco Tello resolved to order Don Juan Ronquillo
column14: since the above was so and the camp could not be maintained
column15: nor the war continued advantageously
column16: to withdraw with his whole camp from Mindanao River. He was first to make a great effort to chastise the enemy in Buhahayen
column17: and then to burn the Spanish settlement and fort and to go to La Caldera
column18: fortify it
column19: and leave there a sufficient garrison with artillery
column20: boats
column21: and provisions for its maintenance and service. Then he was to return to Manila with the rest of his men
column22: after telling their friends in Tampacan that the Spaniards would shortly return to the river better equipped and in greater numbers.Silonga and other chiefs of Buhahayen were not neglecting their defense
column23: since
column24: among other measures taken
column25: they had sent a chief to Terrenate to ask assistance against the Spaniards who had brought war into their homes. Thereupon the king of Terrenate despatched a numerous fleet of caracoas and other boats to Mindanao with cachils [65] and valiant soldiers--more than one thousand fighting men in all--and a quantity of small artillery
column26: in order to force the Spaniards to break camp and depart
column27: even could they do nothing else. When the news reached Buhahayen that this fleet was coming to their defense and support
column28: they made ready and prepared to attack the Spaniards
column29: who also having heard the same news were not careless. Consequently the latter turned their attention more to the main fort
column30: and reduced the number of men in the smaller forts on Buquil River and other posts
column31: mouths
column32: and arms of the same river. These served to strengthen the garrison of the main fort and the armed galleys and other smaller craft
column33: in order to use the latter to resist the expected attack of the enemy. The enemy having gallantly advanced to the very fort of the Spaniards with all their vessels and men
column34: attacked and stormed it with great courage and resolution
column35: in order to effect an entrance. The Spaniards within resisted valiantly
column36: and those outside in the galleys on the river assisted them so effectively that together
column37: with artillery and arquebuses
column38: and at times in close combat with swords and campilans
column39: they made a great slaughter and havoc among the men of Terrenate and those of Buhahayen
column40: who were aiding the former. They killed and wounded a great number of them and captured almost all the caracoas and vessels of the enemy
column41: so that very few boats escaped and they were pursued and burned by the Spaniards
column42: who made many prisoners
column43: and seized immense booty and many weapons from the enemy. As soon as possible after this
column44: the Spaniards turned against the settlements and forts of Buhahayen where some of their results were of so great moment that the enemy
column45: seeing themselves hard pressed and without anyone to help them
column46: sent messages and proposals of peace to Don Juan Ronquillo
column47: which were ended by their rendering recognition and homage
column48: and the renewal of friendship with the people of Tampacan
column49: their ancient enemy. In order to strengthen the friendship
column50: they sealed it by the marriage of the greatest chief and lord of Buhahayen with the daughter of another chief of Tampacan
column51: called Dongonlibor. Thereupon the war was apparently completely ended
column52: provisions were now to be had
column53: and the Spaniards with little precaution crossed and went about the country wherever they wished. The people of Buhahayen promised to dismantle all their forts immediately
column54: for that was one of the conditions of peace. Then the Spaniards returned to their fort and settlement at Tampacan
column55: whence Don Juan Ronquillo immediately sent despatches to Governor Don Francisco Tello
column56: informing him of the different turn that the enterprise had taken. In view of the present condition he requested the governor to issue new instructions as to his procedure
column57: saying that he would wait without making any change
column58: notwithstanding the arrival of the answer which he expected to his first report
column59: for conditions had now become so much better than before that the governor's decision would be different.The governor had already answered Don Joan Ronquillo's first despatch
column60: as we have said above
column61: when the second despatch arrived with news of the successes in Mindanao. Suspicious of the men in the camp who had constantly shown a desire to return to Manila
column62: and little relish for the hardships of war
column63: and fearing lest they would return at the arrival of the first order
column64: executing that order and abandoning the enterprise which had reached such a satisfactory stage; and thinking that it would be unwise to abandon the river: the governor made haste to send a second despatch immediately by various roads
column65: ordering them to pay no attention to his first orders
column66: but to remain in Mindanao
column67: and that he would soon send them what was necessary for further operations.It seems that this message traveled slowly; for
column68: the first having arrived
column69: they obeyed it without any further delay
column70: and camp was raised and the country abandoned. To their former enemy of Buhahayen they gave as a reason that the governor of Manila had summoned them; and to their friends of Tampacan
column71: they said that they would leave men in La Caldera for their security
column72: and that assistance would be sent them from Manila. This news caused as much sorrow and sadness to the latter
column73: as joy to the people of Buhahayen. Then after burning their fort and settlement
column74: the Spaniards embarked all their forces as soon as possible
column75: left the river
column76: and went to La Caldera
column77: twenty-four leguas farther down in the direction of Manila. Having entered port
column78: they built a fortress and left there a garrison of one hundred Spaniards
column79: with some artillery
column80: provisions
column81: and boats for their use.At this juncture
column82: the governor's second message to General Don Joan Ronquillo arrived
column83: to which the latter replied that he was already in La Caldera
column84: and could not return to the river. Then
column86: Don Juan Ronquillo went to Manila with the balance of his fleet
column87: by way of the provinces of Oton
column90: sent to arrest him on the road before he entered the city
column91: and proceeded against him by law for having withdrawn the camp and army from Mindanao River
column92: without awaiting the orders he should have expected after the favorable turn that affairs had taken. Don Juan Ronquillo was set at liberty on showing a private letter from the governor
column93: which the latter had sent him separately with the first instructions
column94: to the effect that he should return to Manila with his troops in any event
column95: for they were needed in the islands for other purposes; and because of this letter Don Juan had determined not to await the second order.

column1: All this, together with the persistency with which the religious begged Taico to restore the merchandise to the Spaniards, resulted in angering him thoroughly, and like the barbarous and so avaricious tyrant that he was, he gave orders to crucify them all and all the religious who preached the religion of Namban [86] in his kingdoms. Five religious who were in the house at Miaco were immediately seized, together with another from the "San Felipe" who had joined them, and all the Japanese preachers and teachers. [87] It was also understood that the persecution would extend to the other orders and Christians in Japon, whereupon all received great fear and confusion. But later Taico's wrath was moderated, for, allowing himself to be entreated, he declared that only the religious who had been found in the house at Miaco, and their companions, the Japanese preachers and teachers, who were arrested, would be crucified; and that all the others, together with the Spaniards of the ship, would be allowed to return to Manila. Fonzanbrandono, brother of Taracabadono, governor of Nangasaqui, was entrusted with the execution of the order. He placed all those who were taken from the house of the Franciscan religious at Miaco on ox-carts, under a strong guard; namely, Fray Pedro Baptista, Fray Martin de Aguirre, Fray Felipe de las Casas, Fray Gonçalo, Fray Francisco Blanco, Fray Francisco de San Miguel, and twenty-six [sic] Japanese preachers and teachers with two boys who were in the service of the religious. Their right ears were cut off, and they were paraded through the streets of Miaco and through those of the cities of Fugimen, Usaca, and Sacai, [88] to the great grief and sorrow of all Christians who saw their sufferings. The sentence and cause of their martyrdom was written on a tablet in Chinese characters, which was carried hanging on a spear; and read as follows.Inasmuch as these men came from the Luzones, from the island of Manila, in the capacity of ambassadors, and were allowed to remain in the city of Miaco, preaching the Christian religion, which in former years I have strictly forbidden: I order that they be executed together with the Japanese who embraced their religion. Therefore these twenty-four [sic] men will be crucified in the city of Nangasaqui. And whereas I again forbid the teaching of this religion henceforward: let all understand this. I command that this decree be carried out; and should any person dare to violate this order, he shall be punished together with his whole family. Given on the first of Echo, and second of the moon. [90]Thus these holy men were taken to Nangasaqui. There, on a hill sown with wheat, in sight of the town and port, and near a house and hospital called San Lazaro, established in Nangasaqui by the said religious on their first coming from the Filipinas, before going up to the capital, they were all crucified in a row. The religious were placed in the middle and the others on either side upon high crosses, with iron staples at their throats, hands, and feet, and with long, sharp iron lances thrust up from below and crosswise through their sides. [91] Thus did they render their souls to their Creator for whom they died with great resolution, on the fifth of February, day of St. Agueda, of the year one thousand five hundred and ninety-seven. They left behind in that ploughed field, and through it in all that kingdom, a great quantity of seed sown, which they watered with their blood, and from which we hope to gather abundant fruit of a numerous conversion to our holy Catholic faith. Before these holy men were crucified, they wrote a letter to Doctor Antonio de Morga, in Manila, by the hand of Fray Martin de Aguirre, which reads word for word as follows.Farewell, Doctor! farewell! Our Lord, not regarding my sins, has, in His mercy, been pleased to make me one of a band of twenty-four [sic] servants of God, who are about to die for love of Him. Six of us are friars of St. Francis, and eighteen are native Japanese. With hopes that many more will follow in the same path, may your Grace receive the last farewell and the last embraces of all this company, for we all acknowledge the support which you have manifested toward the affairs of this conversion. And now, in taking leave, we beg of you--and I especially--to make the protection of this field of Christendom the object of your special care. Since you are a father, and look with favor upon all things which may concern the mission of the religious in this conversion, so may your Grace find one who will protect and intercede for you before God in time of need. Farewell sir! Will your Grace give my last adieu to Doña Juana. May our Lord preserve, etc. From the road to execution, January twenty-eight, one thousand five hundred and ninety-seven.

This king's greed has been much whetted by what he stole from the "San Felipe." It is said that next year he will go to Luzon, and that he does not go this year because of being busy with the Coreans. In order to gain his end, he intends to take the islands of Lequios [92] and Hermosa, throw forces from them into Cagayan, and thence to fall upon Manila, if God does not first put a stop to his advance. Your Graces will attend to what is fitting and necessary. [93]The bodies of the martyrs, although watched for many days by the Japanese, were removed by bits (especially those of the monks) from the crosses as relics by the Christians of the place, who very reverently distributed them around. Together with the staples and the wood of the crosses they are now scattered throughout Christendom.Two other religious of the same band, who were out of the house at the time of the arrest, did not suffer this martyrdom. One, called Fray Geronimo de Jesus, [94] hid himself and went inland, in order not to leave the country; the other, called Fray Agustin Rodriguez, was sheltered by the fathers of the Society, who sent him away by way of Macan. General Don Mathia and the Spaniards of the ship, naked and stripped, left Japon. They embarked at Nangasaqui and went to Manila in various ships which make that voyage for the Japanese and Portuguese. The first news of this event was learned from them in the month of May of ninety-seven. Great grief and sadness was caused by the news, in the death of the holy religious, and in the disturbances which were expected to take place in future dealings between Japon and the Filipinas; as well as in the loss of the galleon and its cargo en route to Nueva España. The value of the vessel was over one million [pesos?], and caused great poverty among the Spaniards. After considering the advisable measures to take under the circumstances, it was ultimately decided that, in order not to allow the matter to pass, a circumspect man should be sent to Japon with letters from the governor to Taicosama. The letters were to set forth the governor's anger at the taking of the ship and merchandise from the Spaniards, and at the killing of the religious; and were also to request Taicosama to make all the reparation possible, by restoring and returning the merchandise to the Spaniards, and the artillery, tackle, and spoils of the vessel that were left, as well as the bodies of the religious whom he had crucified; and Taicosama was so to arrange matters thenceforth, that Spaniards should not be so treated in his kingdom.The governor sent Don Luis Navarrete [95] Fajardo as bearer of this message, and a present of some gold and silver ornaments, swords, and valuable cloth for Taicosama. He also sent him an elephant well caparisoned and covered with silk, and with its naires [i.e., elephant keepers] in the same livery, a thing never before seen in Xapon. According to the custom of that kingdom, Don Luis was to make the present to Taico when he presented his embassy, for the Japanese are wont to give or receive embassies in no other manner. When Don Luys de Navarrete reached Nangasaqui, Taicosama readily sent from the court for the ambassador and for the present which had been sent him from Luzon, for he was anxious to see the gifts, especially the elephant, with which he was greatly delighted. He heard the embassy and replied with much ostentation and display, exculpating himself from the death of the religious upon whom he laid the blame, saying that after he had forbidden them to christianize, or teach their religion, they had disregarded his orders in his own court. Likewise, the seizure of the ship and its merchandise, which entered the port of Hurando in the province of Toza, had been a justifiable procedure, according to the laws of Japon, because all ships lost on its coast belong to the king, with their merchandise. Nevertheless, he added that he was sorry for all that had happened, and that he would return the merchandise had it not been distributed. As to the religious, there was no remedy for it. But he begged the governor of Manila not to send such persons to Xapon, for he had again passed laws forbidding the making of Christians under pain of death. He would deliver whatever had remained of the bodies of the religious and would be glad to have peace and friendship with the Luzon Islands and the Spaniards, and for his part, would endeavor to secure it. He said that if any other vessel came to his kingdom from Manila, he would give orders that it be well received and well treated. With this reply and a letter of the same purport for the governor, Don Luys Navarrete was dismissed. He was given a present for the governor consisting of lances, armor, and catans, considered rare and valuable by the Japanese. The ambassador thereupon left Miaco and went to Nangasaqui, whence by the first ship sailing to Manila, he sent word to Governor Don Francisco concerning his negotiations. But the message itself was taken later to Manila by another person, on account of the illness and death of Don Luis in Nangasaqui. Taicosama rejoiced over his answer to the ambassador, for he had practically done nothing of what was asked of him. His reply was more a display of dissembling and compliments than a desire for friendship with the Spaniards. He boasted and published arrogantly, and his favorites said in the same manner, that the Spaniards had sent him that present and embassy through fear, and as an acknowledgment of tribute and seigniory, so that he might not destroy them as he had threatened them at other times in the past, when Gomez Perez Dasmariñas was governor. And even then the Spaniards had sent him a message and a present by Fray Juan Cobo, the Dominican, and Captain Llanos.
The Japanese Faranda Quiemon sought war with Manila
column2: and the favorites who aided him did not neglect to beg Taico not to lose the opportunity of conquering that city. They said that it would be easy
column3: since there were but few Spaniards there; that a fleet could be sent there quickly
column4: which Faranda would accompany. The latter assured Taico of success
column5: as one who knew the country and its resources. They urged him so continually that Taico entrusted Faranda with the enterprise
column6: and gave him some supplies and other assistance toward it. Faranda began to prepare ships and Chinese for the expedition
column7: which he was never able to carry out; for
column8: being a man naturally low and poor
column9: he possessed neither the ability nor the means sufficient for the enterprise. His protectors themselves did not choose to assist him
column10: and so his preparations were prolonged until the enterprise was abandoned at the death of Taico
column11: and his own death
column12: as will be stated later.Meanwhile news was constantly reaching Manila that a fleet was being equipped in Japon
column13: completely under the supervision of Faranda
column14: and it naturally caused some anxiety among the people in spite of their courage and determination to resist him
column15: for the enemy was arrogant and powerful. Although the city was thoroughly resolved and determined to resist him
column16: yet the governor and city would never show openly that they were aware of the change which Taico was about to make
column17: in order not to precipitate the war or give the other side any reason for hastening it. Trusting to time for the remedy
column18: they so disposed affairs in the city
column19: that they might be ready for any future emergency. They sent the Japanese who had settled in Manila--and they were not few--back to Xapon
column20: and made those who came in merchant ships give up their weapons until their return
column21: which they endeavored to hasten as much as possible; but in all other respects
column22: they treated them hospitably. And because it was heard that Taico intended to take possession of the island of Hermosa
column23: a well-provisioned island off the Chinese coast
column24: very near Luzon
column25: and on the way to Xapon
column26: in order to make it serve as a way-station for his fleet
column27: and thus carry on more easily the war with Manila
column28: the governor sent two ships of the fleet under command of Don Juan de Çamuzio
column29: to reconnoiter that island and all its ports
column30: and the nature of the place
column31: in order to be the first to take possession of it. At least
column32: if means and time should fail him
column33: he was to advise China
column34: and the viceroys of the provinces of Canton and Chincheo
column35: so that
column36: since the latter were old-time enemies of Xapon
column37: they might prevent the Japanese from entering the island
column38: which would prove so harmful to all of them. In these measures and precautions several days were spent in the matter. However
column39: nothing was accomplished by this expedition to Hermosa Island beyond advising Great China of Xapon's designs.Several days after the imprisonment of Father Alonso Ximenez in Cochinchina where Captain and Sargento-mayor Juan Xuarez Gallinato had left him
column40: the kings of Tunquin and Sinua permitted him to return to Manila. He took passage for Macan in a Portuguese vessel. Not only did he arrive unwearied by his voyages
column41: hardships
column42: and imprisonment
column43: but with renewed energy and spirits proposed to set on foot again the expedition to Camboja. Although little was known of the state of affairs in that kingdom
column44: and of the restoration of Prauncar to his throne
column45: he together with other religious of his order
column46: persuaded Don Luys Dasmariñas
column47: upon whom he exercised great influence
column48: and who was then living in Manila
column49: taking no part in government affairs
column50: and inclined him to broach the subject of making this expedition anew and in person and at his own expense
column51: from which would ensue good results for the service of God and of his Majesty. Don Luys discussed the matter with Governor Don Francisco Tello
column52: and offered to bear all the expense of the expedition. But a final decision was postponed until the receipt of news from Camboja
column53: for their only information was that Blas Ruyz and Diego Belloso
column54: leaving Captain Gallinato and his ships in Cochinchina
column55: had gone to Lao.At the departure of Don Juan Ronquillo and his camp from Mindanao River
column56: the people of Tampacan were so disheartened
column57: and the spirit of those of Buhahayen so increased that
column58: in spite of the friendship that they had made
column59: and the homage that they had rendered
column60: they became declared enemies [to the former]. Matters returned to their former state
column61: so that
column62: not only did the inhabitants of Buhahayen not dismantle their forts
column63: as they had promised to do
column64: but they repaired them and committed other excesses against their neighbors of Tampacan. They would have altogether broken into open war
column65: had they not feared that the Spaniards would return better prepared and in larger number
column66: as they had left the garrison at La Caldera with that intention. Thus they let matters stand
column67: neither declaring themselves fully as rebels
column68: nor observing the laws of friendship toward the men of Tampacan and other allies of the Spaniards.Near the island of Mindanao lies an island called Joló
column69: not very large
column70: but thickly populated with natives
column71: all Mahometans. They number about three thousand men
column72: and have their own lord and king. When Governor Francisco de Sande was returning from his expedition to Borneo
column73: he sent Captain Estevan Rodriguez de Figueroa to Joló. He entered the island and reduced the natives to his Majesty's rule as above related. The natives were apportioned to Captain Pedro de Osseguera for his lifetime
column74: and after his death
column75: to his son and successor
column76: Don Pedro de Osseguera. He asked and collected for several years what tribute they chose to give him
column77: which was but slight
column78: without urging more
column79: in order not to make a general disturbance. While Don Juan Ronquillo was with his camp in Mindanao
column80: the men of Joló
column82: were willing to enjoy peace and pay their tribute; but at the departure of the Spaniards
column83: they became lukewarm again. Captain Juan Pacho
column84: who commanded the presidio of La Caldera in Don Juan Ronquillo's absence
column85: having sent some soldiers to barter for wax
column86: the Joloans maltreated them and killed two of them. Juan Pacho
column87: with the intention of punishing this excess of the Joloans
column88: went there in person with several boats and thirty soldiers. As he landed
column89: a considerable body of Joloans descended from their king's town
column90: which is situated on a high and strongly-fortified hill
column91: and attacked the Spaniards. Through the number of the natives and the Spaniards' inability to make use of their arquebuses
column92: on account of a heavy shower
column94: and Captain Juan Pacho and twenty of his followers killed. The rest wounded and in flight took to their boats and returned to La Caldera.

column1: This event caused great grief in Manila
column2: especially because of the reputation lost by it
column3: both among the Joloans
column4: and their neighbors
column5: the people of Mindanao. Although it was considered necessary to punish the Joloans in order to erase this disgrace
column6: yet as this should be done signally and just then there was not sufficient preparation
column7: it was deferred until a better opportunity. Only Captain Villagra was sent immediately as commander of the presidio of La Caldera
column8: with some soldiers. Having arrived there
column9: they spent their time in pleasure
column10: until their provisions were consumed
column11: and the garrison suffering. They were maintained and supported because of the slight protection that the people of Tampacan felt
column12: knowing that there were Spaniards on the island
column13: and hoped for the arrival of more Spaniards
column14: as Don Juan had promised them
column15: and for punishment and vengeance upon the men of Jolo.While affairs in the Filipinas were in this condition
column16: ships from Nueva España arrived at Manila
column17: in the month of May
column18: one thousand five hundred and ninety-eight. These ships brought despatches ordering the reëstablishment of the royal Audiencia
column19: which had been suppressed in the Filipinas some years before. Don Francisco Tello
column20: who was governing the country
column21: was named and appointed its president; Doctor Antonio de Morga and Licentiates Christoval Telles Almaçan and Alvaro Rodriguez Zambrano
column22: auditors; and Licentiate Geronymo de Salazar
column23: fiscal; and other officials of the Audiencia were also appointed. By the same ships arrived the archbishop
column24: Fray Ignacio de Sanctivañes
column25: who enjoyed the archbishopric only for a short time
column26: for he died of dysentery in
column27: the month of August of the same year. The bishop of Sebu
column28: Fray Pedro de Agurto came also. On the eighth of May of this year-five hundred and ninety-eight
column29: the royal seal of the Audiencia was received. It was taken from the monastery of San Agustin to the cathedral upon a horse caparisoned with cloth of gold and crimson
column30: and under a canopy of the same material. The staves of the canopy were carried by the regidors of the city
column31: who were clad in robes of crimson velvet lined with white silver cloth
column32: and in breeches and doublets of the same material. The horse that carried the seal in a box of cloth of gold covered with brocade was led on the right by him who held the office of alguacil-mayor
column33: who was clad in cloth of gold and wore no cloak. Surrounding the horse walked the president and auditors
column34: all afoot and bareheaded. In front walked a throng of citizens clad in costly gala dress; behind followed the whole camp and the soldiers
column35: with their drums and banners
column36: and their arms in hand
column37: and the captains and officers at their posts
column38: with the master-of-camp preceding them
column39: staff in hand. The streets and windows were richly adorned with quantities of tapestry and finery
column40: and many triumphal arches
column41: and there was music from flutes
column42: trumpets
column43: and other instruments. When the seal was taken to the door of the cathedral of Manila
column44: the archbishop in pontifical robes came out with the cross
column45: accompanied by the chapter and clergy of the church to receive it. Having lifted the box containing the seal from the horse under the canopy
column46: the archbishop placed it in the hands of the president. Then the auditors went into the church with him
column47: while the band of singers intoned the Te Deum laudamus. They reached the main altar
column48: upon the steps of which stood a stool covered with brocade. Upon this they placed the box with the seal. All knelt and the archbishop chanted certain prayers to the Holy Spirit for the health and good government of the king
column49: our sovereign. Then the president took the box with the seal
column50: and with the same order and music with which it had been brought into the church it was carried out and replaced upon the horse. The archbishop and clergy remained at the door of the church
column51: while the cortége proceeded to the royal buildings. The said box containing the royal seal was placed and left in a beautifully-adorned apartment
column52: with a covering of cloth of gold and crimson
column53: on a table covered with brocade and cushions of the same material
column54: which stood under a canopy of crimson velvet embroidered with the royal arms. Then the royal order for the establishment of the Audiencia was publicly read there
column55: and the nominations for president
column56: auditors
column57: and fiscal. Homage was done them and the usual oath administered. The president proceeded to the Audiencia hall
column58: where the court rooms were well arranged and contained a canopy for the royal arms. There the president
column59: auditors
column60: and fiscal took their seats and received the ministers and officials of the Audiencia. Then the ordinances of the Audiencia were read in the presence of as many citizens as could find room in the hall. This completed the establishment of the Audiencia on that day. Thenceforth it has exercised its functions
column61: and has had charge and disposition in all cases
column62: both civil and criminal
column63: of its district. The latter includes the Filipinas Islands and all the mainland
column64: of China discovered or to be discovered. In charge of the president who acts as governor of the land

column66: ordinances
column67: and special orders
column68: which were acted on and brought before the Audiencia.

column1: The third is that by this means we would avoid the excessive commerce of the Sangleys in that city [i.e.
column2: Manila]
column3: who cause the harm which your Grace knows
column4: and even that which we do not know. They are people who
column5: the less they are admitted
column6: the better will it be for us in every respect. Hence there is no need of there being more of them than the number required for the service of the community; and then they would neither raise the price of provisions
column7: nor retail what remains in the country
column8: as they do now. Thus many pernicious sins which they commit and teach to the natives would be avoided. Although there seems to be some difficulty in establishing this and in smoothing down the Portuguese
column9: still it might be accomplished.The fourth reason is that
column10: if the purchase is made here
column11: it will reach that city [i.e.
column12: Manila] by Christmas
column13: and each man would store his property in his house
column14: and prepare and arrange it; and then
column15: even should the ships from Castilla arrive early
column16: no loss would be suffered as at present--when
column17: if those ships arrive before the goods purchased from China [reach Manila] the merchandise rises a hundred per cent.The fifth reason is that the ships might easily take in cargo any time in the month of May
column18: and take advantage of the first vendavals
column19: which sometimes begin by the middle of June or before. By sailing then
column20: they run less risk
column21: and will reach Nueva España one month or even two months earlier. Then
column22: they can leave that country in January and come here [i.e.
column23: to the Filipinas] by April without any of the dangers which beset them among these islands if they sail late
column24: as we know.The sixth reason is that the many inconveniences now existing at the time of the purchase [in Manila] would be avoided--inconveniences with which your Grace is acquainted--and the citizens would have less trouble. Also in respect to the lading and its allotment [i.e.
column25: of shipping room] a better system could certainly be followed
column26: and it would be known who is to share in it. Things would be better remedied
column27: because neither the money of Mexico nor that of companies would be allowed to be employed. The strict prevention of this alone would be sufficient to assure prosperity to Manila in a short time; for
column28: if only the inhabitants were to send their invested property
column29: it is certain that all the machinery of the money of the Mexicans would have to be employed on the goods sent from here--I mean from Manila--if they do not allow the Mexicans to purchase in that city [i.e.
column30: Manila]. And if less merchandise is sent from here [i.e.
column31: China
column32: and consequently Manila] and there are more buyers there [i.e.
column33: in Mexico]
column34: the goods would be worth double. This is self-evident
column35: and if
column36: as your Graces have already begun to remedy this matter
column37: the measure be rigorously carried still farther
column38: that city [i.e.
column39: Manila] must prosper greatly. For
column40: by not sending to Nueva España any other produce except that from that city [i.e.
column41: Manila] mainly purchased in this country [i.e.
column42: China]
column43: Manila would prosper as greatly as one could desire. If we consider the benefit and favor which his Majesty confers upon us in this matter
column44: we would esteem it much more than we do now. But I believe that we shall regret it
column45: when
column46: perchance
column47: we are deprived of it. Perhaps some one would say
column48: in opposition to what I have said about coming to purchase here
column49: that his Majesty would be defrauded of the customs and duties which the Sangleys now pay
column50: and of their tribute. But there is a remedy for all this
column51: for with the freight duties alone his Majesty would save much more; as also by buying ammunitions here and other articles which he needs for the conservation of that country [i.e.
column52: the islands] twice as cheaply and abundantly
column53: and without depending on the Chinese to bring them at their leisure
column54: who at times--and indeed every year--leave us without them
column55: since we are forced to go to get them. As far as the tribute is concerned
column56: I believe that his Majesty would be better served if there were no Sangleys there at all
column57: than by receiving the tribute. And it might happen
column58: through this way
column59: if our Lord ordered it
column60: that a door might be opened for the preaching of the gospel and for the conversion of the people
column61: a thing desired so earnestly by his Majesty
column62: and especially aimed at by him. After all
column63: things require a beginning
column64: and the road would be opened
column65: although at present it seems shut; for
column66: if we hope that the Portuguese attempt this
column67: I do not know when they will do it
column68: considering that they have not tried to do so
column69: for so long as they have been settled here. Even the Sangleys say that the Portuguese began like ourselves. At first they went to and fro; then two sick men remained; the next year they built four houses; and thus they continued to increase. I know that there is no other difficulty for us to do likewise than that which the Portuguese offer. To return to the Portuguese opposition
column70: it is something amazing
column71: for not only are they vexed at our coming here
column72: but also at our going to Camboja or to Sian. They assert that those districts are theirs
column73: but I cannot see why they so designate them--for it is just the contrary--unless it be because we have allowed them
column74: through our negligence
column75: to seize our possessions near the strait of Malaca
column76: and enter the line of demarcation falling to the crown of Castilla
column77: as I would make them fully understand if an opportunity were presented. One can read in Historia de las Indias [111] [i.e.
column78: History of the Indias] in the one hundred and second chapter
column79: and before and after it
column80: that
column81: at the request of the Portuguese
column82: his Holiness drew the said line from three hundred and seventy leguas west of the islands of Caboverde
column83: which were called the Espericas. The one hundred and eighty degrees of longitude falling to the Portuguese terminate and end as abovesaid
column84: near the above-mentioned strait. All the rest belongs to us. Furthermore
column85: since we are subjects of one king
column86: how do we suffer them to forbid us all our trade? Why do they bar us from Maluco
column91: and all the rest of this archipelago? What are we to do then
column92: if they wish to seize everything? Surely this is a very unreasonable proceeding. I have dwelt on this matter in order to express my feelings. Not until our departure shall I write to your Grace about the fertility and nature of the country
column93: and of its greatness. Then I shall endeavor to give a full account of the land
column94: and to mark out this coast
column95: for nothing is put down correctly.

column1: It has been already related that the galliot
column2: one of the ships of Don Luis Dasmariñas's fleet
column3: in which Luis Ortiz and twenty-five Spaniards had sailed
column4: after having put into Cagayan and refitted there
column5: sailed again during fairly good weather to find the fleet. This ship although so inadequate to resist storms at sea
column6: was permitted
column7: through God's mercy
column8: to encounter those which it met without being wrecked. It made its way along the coast of Cochinchina and Champan
column9: inside the shoals of Aynao
column10: and reached the bar of Camboja. Expecting to find all or some of the ships of its convoy within the bar
column11: it ascended the river as far as the city of Chordemuco. There they found Diego Belloso and Blas Ruys de Hernan Gonçalez
column12: with some Castilians who had joined them
column13: and other Portuguese who had come by way of Malaca
column14: and with whose assistance many battles had been won in favor of King Prauncar
column15: who had been restored to his kingdom
column16: although some of his provinces had not been entirely pacified. It was learned there that neither Don Luis Dasmariñas nor any other of his fleet had reached Camboja. Those in the galliot said that Don Luis was coming in person with a large force of ships
column17: men
column18: arms
column19: and some religious
column20: to accomplish what he had always desired to do in that kingdom; that he would not be long in coming; and that their galliot and crew belonged to his fleet. Blas Ruis and his Castilian companions greatly rejoiced over so opportune news. The former thought that everything was turning out well
column21: and that now
column22: according to the present state of affairs
column23: matters would be accomplished and settled as they wished. Diego Belloso and his party
column24: although they did not show their regret
column25: were not so pleased
column26: for they much preferred the happy termination and reward of this expedition to be for the Portuguese and the government of India. They had had certain quarrels and disputes with Blas Ruis over this. But seeing that the affair had reached this state
column27: they conformed to the times. Thereupon all joined together
column28: Portuguese and Castilians
column29: and informed Prauncar and his mandarins of the arrival of Alférez Luis Ortiz with his galliot and companions
column30: saying that they were part of a large fleet which would shortly arrive
column31: and that Don Luis Dasmariñas was coming in it in person
column32: with religious and men to aid and serve the king
column33: in conformity to what he himself had requested in his letter to Manila
column34: several months before. The king seemed pleased at this
column35: and so did some of his mandarins who liked the Spaniards
column36: and recognized what benefits they had derived from them hitherto. These believed that the matter would turn out as it was represented to them. But the king's stepmother
column37: and other mandarins of her party
column38: especially the Moro Malay Ocuña Lacasamana
column39: were vexed at the arrival of the Spaniards
column40: for they thought that the latter
column41: being valiant men
column42: numerous
column43: and so courageous
column44: as they already knew
column45: would dominate everything
column46: or at least would take the best; moreover they alone wished to deal with King Prauncar. Thus their aversion for Spanish affairs became known to be as great as the favor with which Prauncar
column47: on the contrary
column48: regarded them. The latter immediately assigned the Spaniards a position with their ship near the city
column49: at the place which Blas Ruiz and Diego Belloso occupied.Before Don Luis Dasmariñas left Manila with his fleet
column50: Captain Joan de Mendoça Gamboa requested Governor Don Francisco Tello to allow him to go to the kingdom of Sian with a moderate-sized ship
column51: in order to trade. For the greater security of his voyage and business
column52: he asked the governor to give him letters to the king of Sian

column55: and commerce which Joan Tello de Aguirre had contracted with Sian the year before. Seeing that Don Luis Dasmariñas
column56: who was on the way to Camboja
column57: had left in Manila for another occasion some ammunition and other things of use to his fleet
column58: Don Joan
column59: in order better to facilitate the granting of his request
column60: offered to take these stores on board his ship and sail round by way of Camboja
column61: where he supposed that he would find Don Luis Dasmariñas
column62: and deliver them to him. The governor thought the two proposals timely
column63: and having furnished him with the necessary despatches
