column34: in subduing them and repacifying them.The apparel and clothing of these natives of Luzon before the entrance of the Spaniards into the country were generally
column35: for the men
column36: certain short collarless garments of cangan
column37: sewed together in the front
column38: and with short sleeves
column39: and reaching slightly below the waist; some were blue and others black
column40: while the chiefs had some red ones
column41: called chinanas. [218] They also wore a strip of colored cloth wrapped about the waist
column42: and passed between the legs
column43: so that it covered the privy parts
column44: reaching half-way down the thigh; these are called bahaques. [219] They go with legs bare
column45: feet unshod
column46: and the head uncovered
column47: wrapping a narrow cloth
column48: called potong [220] just below it
column49: with which they bind the forehead and temples. About their necks they wear gold necklaces
column50: wrought like spun wax
column51: [221] and with links in our fashion
column52: some larger than others. On their arms they wear armlets of wrought gold
column53: which they call calombigas
column54: and which are very large and made in different patterns. Some wear strings of precious stones--cornelians and agates; and other blue and white stones
column55: which they esteem highly. [222] They wear around the legs some strings of these stones
column56: and certain cords
column57: covered with black pitch in many foldings
column58: as garters. [223]In a province called Zambales
column59: they wear the head shaved from the middle forward. On the skull they have a huge lock of loose hair. [224] The women throughout this island wear small jackets [sayuelos] with sleeves of the same kinds of cloth and of all colors
column60: called varos. [225] They wear no shifts
column61: but certain white cotton garments which are wrapped about the waist and fall to the feet
column62: while other dyed cloths are wrapped about the body
column63: like kirtles
column64: and are very graceful. The principal women have crimson ones
column65: and some of silk
column66: while others are woven with gold
column67: and adorned with fringe and other ornaments. They wear many gold necklaces about the neck
column68: calumbigas on the wrists
column69: large earrings of wrought gold in the ears
column70: and rings of gold and precious stones. Their black hair is done up in a very graceful knot on the head. Since the Spaniards came to the country many Indians do not wear bahaques
column71: but wide drawers of the same cloths and materials
column72: and hats on their heads. The chiefs wear braids of wrought gold containing many designs
column73: while many of them wear shoes. The chief women also wear beautiful shoes
column74: many of them having shoes of velvet adorned with gold
column75: and white garments like petticoats.

column1: Men and women
column2: and especially the chief people
column3: are very clean and neat in their persons and clothing
column4: and of pleasing address and grace. They dress their hair carefully
column5: and regard it as being more ornamental when it is very black. They wash it with water in which has been boiled the bark of a tree called gogo. [226] They anoint it with aljonjoli oil
column6: prepared with musk
column7: and other perfumes. All are very careful of their teeth
column8: which from a very early age they file and render even
column9: with stones and iron. [227] They dye them a black color
column10: which is lasting
column11: and which preserves their teeth until they are very old
column12: although it is ugly to look at. [228]They quite generally bathe the entire body in the rivers and creeks
column13: both young and old
column14: without reflecting that it could at any time be injurious to them; [229] for in their baths do they find their best medicines. When an infant is born
column15: they immediately bathe it
column16: and the mother likewise. The women have needlework as their employment and occupation
column17: and they are very clever at it
column18: and at all kinds of sewing. They weave cloth and spin cotton
column19: and serve in the houses of their husbands and fathers. They pound the rice for eating
column20: [230] and prepare the other food. They raise fowls and swine
column21: and keep the houses
column22: while the men are engaged in the labors of the field
column23: and in their fishing
column24: navigation
column25: and trading. They are not very chaste
column26: either single or married women; while their husbands
column27: fathers
column28: or brothers are not very jealous or anxious about it. Both men and women are so selfish and greedy that
column29: if they are paid
column30: they are easily won over. When the husband finds his wife in adultery
column31: he is smoothed and pacified without any trouble--although
column32: since they have known Spaniards
column33: some of those who assume to be more enlightened among them have sometimes killed the adulterers. Both men and women
column34: especially the chiefs
column35: walk slowly and sedately when upon their visits
column36: and when going through the streets and to the temples; and are accompanied by many slaves
column37: both male and female
column38: with parasols of silk which they carry to protect them from the sun and rain. The women walk ahead and their female servants and slaves follow them; behind these walk their husbands
column39: fathers
column40: or brothers
column41: with their man-servants and slaves. [231]Their ordinary food is rice pounded in wooden mortars
column42: and cooked--this is called morisqueta
column43: [232] and is the ordinary bread of the whole country--boiled fish (which is very abundant)
column44: the flesh of swine
column45: deer
column46: and wild buffaloes (which they call carabaos). Meat and fish they relish better when it has begun to spoil and when it stinks. [233] They also eat boiled camotes (which are sweet potatoes)
column47: beans
column48: quilites [234] and other vegetables; all kinds of bananas
column49: guavas
column50: pineapples
column51: custard apples
column52: many varieties of oranges
column53: and other varieties of fruits and herbs
column54: with which the country teems. Their drink is a wine made from the tops of cocoa and nipa palm
column55: of which there is a great abundance. They are grown and tended like vineyards
column56: although without so much toil and labor. Drawing off the tuba
column57: [235] they distil it
column58: using for alembics their own little furnaces and utensils
column59: to a greater or less strength
column60: and it becomes brandy. This is drunk throughout the islands. It is a wine of the clarity of water
column61: but strong and dry. If it be used with moderation
column62: it acts as a medicine for the stomach
column63: and is a protection against humors and all sorts of rheums. Mixed with Spanish wine
column64: it makes a mild liquor
column65: and one very palatable and healthful.In the assemblies
column66: marriages
column67: and feasts of the natives of these islands
column68: the chief thing consists in drinking this wine
column69: day and night
column70: without ceasing
column71: when the turn of each comes
column72: some singing and others drinking. As a consequence
column73: they generally become intoxicated without this vice being regarded as a dishonor or disgrace. [236]

column1: The weapons of this people are
column2: in some provinces
column3: bow and arrows. But those generally used throughout the islands are moderate-sized spears with well-made points; and certain shields of light wood
column4: with their armholes fastened on the inside. These cover them from top to toe
column5: and are called carasas [kalasag]. At the waist they carry a dagger four fingers in breadth
column6: the blade pointed
column7: and a third of a vara in length; the hilt is of gold or ivory. The pommel is open and has two cross bars or projections
column8: without any other guard. They are called bararaos. They have two cutting edges
column9: and are kept in wooden scabbards
column10: or those of buffalo-horn
column11: admirably wrought. [237] With these they strike with the point
column12: but more generally with the edge. When they go in pursuit of their opponent
column13: they show great dexterity in seizing his hair with one hand
column14: while with the other they cut off his head with one stroke of the bararao
column15: and carry it away. They afterward keep the heads suspended in their houses
column16: where they may be seen; and of these they make a display
column17: in order to be considered as valiant
column18: and avengers of their enemies and of the injuries committed by them. [238]Since they have seen the Spaniards use their weapons
column19: many of the natives handle the arquebuses and muskets quite skilfully. Before the arrival of the Spaniards they had bronze culverins and other pieces of cast iron
column20: with which they defended their forts and settlements
column21: although their powder is not so well refined as that of the Spaniards.Their ships and boats are of many kinds; for on the rivers and creeks inland they use certain very large canoes
column22: each made from one log
column23: and others fitted with benches and made from planks
column24: and built up on keels. They have vireys and barangays
column25: which are certain quick and light vessels that lie low in the water
column26: put together with little wooden nails. These are as slender at the stern as at the bow
column27: and they can hold a number of rowers on both sides
column28: who propel their vessels with bucçeyes or paddles
column29: and with gaones [239] on the outside of the vessel; and they time their rowing to the accompaniment of some who sing in their language refrains by which they understand whether to hasten or retard their rowing. [240] Above the rowers is a platform or gangway
column30: built of bamboo
column31: upon which the fighting-men stand
column32: in order not to interfere with the rowing of the oarsmen. In accordance with the capacity of the vessels is the number of men on these gangways. From that place they manage the sail
column33: which is square and made of linen
column34: and hoisted on a support or yard made of two thick bamboos
column35: which serves as a mast. When the vessel is large
column36: it also has a foresail of the same form. Both yards
column37: with their tackle
column38: can be lowered upon the gangway when the weather is rough. The helmsmen are stationed in the stern to steer. It carries another bamboo framework on the gangway itself; and upon this
column39: when the sun shines hot
column40: or it rains
column41: they stretch an awning made from some mats
column42: woven from palm-leaves. These are very bulky and close
column43: and are called cayanes [241] Thus all the ship and its crew are covered and protected. There are also other bamboo frameworks for each side of the vessel
column44: which are so long as the vessel
column45: and securely fastened on. They skim the water
column46: without hindering the rowing
column47: and serve as a counterpoise
column48: so that the ship cannot overturn nor upset
column49: however heavy the sea
column50: or strong the wind against the sail. It may happen that the entire hull of these vessels
column51: which have no decks
column52: may fill with water and remain between wind and water
column53: even until it is destroyed and broken up
column54: without sinking
column55: because of these counterpoises. These vessels have been used commonly throughout the islands since olden times. They have other larger vessels called caracoas
column56: lapis
column57: and tapaques
column58: which are used to carry their merchandise
column59: and which are very suitable
column60: as they are roomy and draw but little water. They generally drag them ashore every night
column61: at the mouths of rivers and creeks
column62: among which they always navigate without going into the open sea or leaving the shore. All the natives can row and manage these boats. Some are so long that they can carry one hundred rowers on a side and thirty soldiers above to fight. The boats commonly used are barangays and vireys
column63: which carry a less crew and fighting force. Now they put many of them together with iron nails instead of the wooden pegs and the joints in the planks
column64: while the helms and bows have beaks like Castilian boats. [242]

column1: The land is well shaded in all parts by trees of different kinds
column2: and fruit-trees which beautify it throughout the year
column3: both along the shore and inland among the plains and mountains. It is very full of large and small rivers
column4: of good fresh water
column5: which flow into the sea. All of them are navigable
column6: and abound in all kinds of fish
column7: which are very pleasant to the taste. For the above reason there is a large supply of lumber
column8: which is cut and sawed
column9: dragged to the rivers
column10: and brought down
column11: by the natives. This lumber is very useful for houses and buildings
column12: and for the construction of small and large vessels. Many very straight thick trees
column13: light and pliable
column14: are found
column15: which are used as masts for ships and galleons. Consequently
column16: vessels of any size may be fitted with masts from these trees
column17: made of one piece of timber
column18: without its being necessary to splice them or make them of different pieces. For the hulls of the ships
column19: the keels
column20: futtock-timbers
column21: top-timbers
column22: and any other kinds of supports and braces
column23: compass-timbers
column24: transoms
column25: knees small and large
column26: and rudders
column27: all sorts of good timber are easily found; as well as good planking for the sides
column28: decks
column29: and upper-works
column30: from very suitable woods. [243]There are many native fruit-trees
column31: such as the sanctors
column32: mabolos
column33: tamarinds
column34: nancas
column35: custard-apples
column36: papaws
column37: guavas
column38: and everywhere many oranges
column39: of all kinds--large and small
column40: sweet and sour; citrons
column41: lemons
column42: and ten or twelve varieties of very healthful and palatable bananas. [244] There are many cocoa-palms bearing fruit of pleasant taste--from which is made wine and common oil
column43: which is a very healing remedy for wounds; and other wild palms of the forests--that do not yield cocoa-nuts
column44: but serve as wood
column45: and from whose bark is made bonote
column46: a tow for rigging and cables
column47: and also for calking ships. Efforts have been made to plant olives and quinces
column48: and other fruit-trees of España
column49: but as yet they have had no success
column50: except with pomegranates and grapevines
column51: which bear fruit the second year. These bear abundance of exceedingly good grapes three times a year; and some fig-trees have succeeded. Vegetables of every kind grow well and very abundantly
column52: but do not seed
column53: and it is always necessary to bring the seeds from Castilla
column54: China
column55: or Japon.In the Cagayan provinces are found chestnut-trees
column56: which produce fruit. In other districts are found pines and other trees which yield certain very large pine-nuts
column57: with a hard shell and a pleasant taste
column58: which are called piles. [245] There is abundance of cedar which is called calanta
column59: a beautiful red wood called asana
column60: [246] ebony of various qualities
column61: and many other precious woods for all uses. The meat generally eaten is that of swine
column62: of which there is a great abundance
column63: and it is very palatable and wholesome.Beef is eaten
column64: cattle being raised abundantly in stock-farms in many different parts of the islands. The cattle are bred from those of China and Nueva España. [247] The Chinese cattle are small
column65: and excellent breeders. Their horns are very small and twisted
column66: and some cattle can move them. They have a large hump upon the shoulders
column67: and are very manageable beasts. There are plenty of fowls like those of Castilla
column68: and others very large
column69: which are bred from fowls brought from China. They are very palatable
column70: and make fine capons. Some of these fowls are black in feather
column71: skin
column72: flesh
column73: and bones
column74: and are pleasant to the taste. [248] Many geese are raised
column75: as well as swans
column76: ducks
column77: and tame pigeons brought from China. There is abundance of flesh of wild game
column78: such as venison
column79: and wild boars
column80: and in some parts porcupines. There are many buffaloes
column82: which are raised in the fields and are very spirited; others are brought tame from China; these are very numerous
column83: and very handsome. These last are used only for milking
column84: and their milk is thicker and more palatable than that of cows.

column1: Goats and kids are raised, although their flesh is not savory, because of the humidity of the country. These animals sicken and die for that reason, and because they eat certain poisonous herbs. Ewes and rams, although often brought from Nueva España, never multiply. Consequently there are none of these animals, for the climate and pasturage has not as yet seemed suitable for them. [249] There were no horses, mares, or asses in the islands, until the Spaniards had them brought from China and brought them from Nueva España. Asses and mules are very rare, but there are many horses and mares. Some farms are being stocked with them, and those born there (mixed breeds for the most part) turn out well, and have good colors, are good tempered and willing to work, and are of medium size. Those brought from China are small, very strong, good goers, treacherous, quarrelsome, and bad-tempered. Some horses of good colors are brought from Japon. They have well-shaped bodies, thick hair, large fetlocks, large legs and front hoofs, which makes them look like draft-horses. Their heads are rather large, and their mouths hard. They run but slowly, but walk well, and are spirited, and of much mettle. The daily feed of the horses consists throughout the year of green provender, [250] besides rice in the husk, which keeps them very fat. [251]There are many fowls and field birds, and wild birds of wonderful colors and very beautiful. There are no singing birds suitable for keeping in cages, although some calendar larks [Calandrias] called fimbaros, [252] smaller than those of España, are brought from Japon, whose song is most sweet. There are many turtle-doves, ring-doves; other doves with an extremely green plumage, and red feet and beaks; and others that are white with a red spot on the breast, like a pelican. Instead of quail, there are certain birds resembling them, but smaller, which are called povos [253] and other smaller birds called mayuelas. [254] There are many wild chickens and cocks, which are very small, and taste like partridge. There are royal, white, and grey herons, flycatchers, and other shore birds, ducks, lavancos, [255] crested cranes, sea-crows, eagles, eagle-owls, and other birds of prey, although none are used for hawking. There are jays and thrushes as in España, and white storks and cranes. [256] They do not rear peacocks, rabbits, or hares, although they have tried to do so. It is believed that the wild animals in the forests and fields eat and destroy them, namely, the cats, foxes, badgers, and large and small rats, which are very numerous, and other land animals. [257]Throughout these islands are found a great number of monkeys, of various sizes, with which at times the trees are covered. There are green and white parrots, but they are stupid in talking; and very small parroquets, of beautiful green and red colors, which talk as little. The forests and settlements have many serpents, of various colors, which are generally larger than those of Castilla. Some have been seen in the forests of unusual size, and wonderful to behold. [258] The most harmful are certain slender snakes, of less than one vara in length, which dart down upon passersby from the trees (where they generally hang), and sting them; their venom is so powerful that within twenty-four hours the person dies raving.There are many very large scorpions in the rivers and creeks, and a great number of crocodiles, which are very bloodthirsty and cruel. They quite commonly pull from their bancas the natives who go in those boats, and cause many injuries among the horned cattle and the horses of the stock-farms, when they go to drink. And although the people fish for them often and kill them, they are never diminished in number. For that reason, the natives set closely-grated divisions and enclosures in the rivers and creeks of their settlements, where they bathe. There they enter the water to bathe, secure from those monsters, which they fear so greatly that they venerate and adore them, as if they were beings superior to themselves. All their oaths and execrations, and those which are of any weight with them (even among the Christians) are, thus expressed: "So may the crocodile kill him!" They call the crocodile buhaya in their language. It has happened when some one has sworn falsely, or when he has broken his word, that then some accident has occurred to him with the crocodile, which God, whom he offends, has so permitted for the sake of the authority and purity of the truth, and the promise of it. [259]

The fisheries of sea and rivers are most abundant, and include all kinds of fish; both of fresh and salt water. These are generally used as food throughout the entire country. There are many good sardines, sea-eels, sea-breams (which they call bacocos), daces, skates, bicudas, tanguingues, soles, plantanos, [260] taraquitos, needle-fish, gilt-heads, and eels; large oysters, mussels, [261] porçebes, crawfish, shrimp, sea-spiders, center-fish, and all kinds of cockles, shad, white fish, and in the Tajo River of Cagayan, [262] during their season, a great number of bobos, which come down to spawn at the bar. In the lake of Bonbon, a quantity of tunny-fish, not so large as those of España, but of the same shape, flesh, and taste, are caught. Many sea-fish are found in the sea, such as whales, sharks, caellas, marajos, bufeos, and other unknown species of extraordinary forms and size. In the year of five hundred and ninety-six, during a furious storm in the islands, a fish was flung into shallow water on one of the Luzon coasts near the province of Camarines. It was so huge and misshapen, that although it lay in more than three and one-half braças of water, it could not again get afloat, and died there. The natives said that they had never seen anything like it, nor another shaped like it. Its head was of wonderful size and fierce aspect. On its frontal it bore two horns, which pointed toward its back. One of them was taken to Manila. It was covered with its skin or hide, but had no hair or scales. It was white, and twenty feet long. Where it joined the head it was as thick as the thigh, and gradually tapered proportionally to the tip. It was somewhat curved and not very round; and to all appearances, quite solid. It caused great wonder in all beholders. [263]There is a fresh-water lake in the island of Luzon, five leguas from Manila, which contains a quantity of fish. Many rivers flow into this lake, and it empties into the sea through the river flowing from it to Manila. It is called La Laguna de Bay ["Bay Lake"]. It is thirty leguas in circumference, and has an uninhabited island in its middle, where game abounds. [264] Its shores are lined with many native villages. The natives navigate the lake, and commonly cross it in their skiffs. At times it is quite stormy and dangerous to navigate, when the north winds blow, for these winds make it very boisterous, although it is very deep.Twenty leguas from Manila, in the province of Bonbon, is another lake of the same name [Bonbon], not so extensive as the former, but with a great abundance of fish. The natives' method of catching them is by making corrals [265] of bejucos, which are certain slender canes or rushes, solid and very pliant and strong; these are employed for making cables for the natives' boats, as well as other kinds of ropes. They catch the fish inside these corrals, having made the enclosures fast by means of stakes. They also catch the fish in wicker baskets made from the bejucos, but most generally with atarrayas, [266] esparaveles, other small barrederas, [267] and with hand lines and hooks. [268] The most usual food of the natives is a fish as small as pejerreyes. [269] They dry and cure these fish in the sun and air, and cook them in many styles. They like them better than large fish. It is called laulau among them. [270]
All these islands are
column2: in many districts
column3: rich in placers and mines of gold
column4: a metal which the natives dig and work. However
column5: since the advent of the Spaniards in the land
column6: the natives proceed more slowly in this
column7: and content themselves with what they already possess in jewels and gold ingots
column8: handed down from antiquity and inherited from their ancestors. [282] This is considerable
column9: for he must be poor and wretched who has no gold chains
column10: calombigas [bracelets]
column11: and earrings.Some placers and mines were worked at Paracali in the province of Camarines
column12: where there is good gold mixed with copper. This commodity is also traded in the Ylocos
column13: for at the rear of this province
column14: which borders the seacoast
column15: are certain lofty and rugged mountains which extend as far as Cagayan. On the slopes of these mountains
column16: in the interior
column17: live many natives
column18: as yet unsubdued
column19: and among whom no incursion has been made
column20: who are called Ygolotes. These natives possess rich mines
column21: many of gold and silver mixed. They are wont to dig from them only the amount necessary for their wants. They descend to certain places to trade this gold (without completing its refining or preparation)
column22: with the Ylocos; there they exchange it for rice
column23: swine
column24: carabaos
column25: cloth
column26: and other things that they need. [283] The Ylocos complete its refining and preparation
column27: and by their medium it is distributed throughout the country. Although an effort has been made with these Ygolotes to discover their mines
column28: and how they work them
column29: and their method of working the metal
column30: nothing definite has been learned
column31: for the Ygolotes fear that the Spaniards will go to seek them for their gold
column32: and say that they keep the gold better in the earth than in their houses. [284]There are also many gold mines and placers in the other islands
column33: especially among the Pintados
column34: on the Botuan River in Mindanao
column35: and in Sebu
column36: where a mine of good gold is worked
column37: called Taribon. If the industry and efforts of the Spaniards were to be converted into the working of the gold
column38: as much would be obtained from any one of these islands as from those provinces which produce the most in the world. But since they attend to other means of gain rather than to this
column39: as will be told in due time
column40: they do not pay the proper attention to this matter.In some of these islands pearl oysters are found
column41: especially in the Calamianes
column42: where some have been obtained that are large and exceedingly clear and lustrous. [285] Neither is this means of profit utilized. In all parts
column43: seed pearls are found in the ordinary oysters
column44: and there are oysters as large as a buckler. From the [shells of the] latter the natives manufacture beautiful articles. There are also very large sea turtles in all the islands. Their shells are utilized by the natives
column45: and sold as an article of commerce to the Chinese and Portuguese
column46: and other nations who go after them and esteem them highly
column47: because of the beautiful things made from them.On the coasts of any of these islands are found many small white snail shells
column48: called siguei. The natives gather them and sell them by measure to the Siamese
column49: Cambodians
column50: Pantanes
column51: and other peoples of the mainland. It serves there as money
column52: and those nations trade with it
column53: as they do with cacao-beans in Nueva España. [286]In this island of Luzon
column54: especially in the provinces of Manila
column55: Panpanga
column56: Pangasinan
column57: and Ylocos
column58: certain earthenware jars [tibores] are found among the natives. They are very old
column59: of a brownish color
column60: and not handsome. Some are of medium size
column61: and others are smaller
column62: and they have certain marks and stamps. The natives are unable to give any explanation of where or when they got them
column63: for now they are not brought to the islands or made there. The Japanese seek them and esteem them
column64: for they have found that the root of a plant called cha [tea]--which is drunk hot
column65: as a great refreshment and medicine
column66: among the kings and lords of Japon--is preserved and keeps only in these tibors. These are so highly valued throughout Japon
column67: that they are regarded as the most precious jewels of their closets and household furniture. A tibor is worth a great sum
column68: and the Japanese adorn them outside with fine gold beautifully chased
column69: and keep them in brocade cases. Some tibors are valued and sold for two thousand taes of eleven reals to the tae
column70: or for less
column71: according to the quality of the tibor. It makes no difference if they are cracked or chipped
column72: for that does not hinder them from holding the tea. The natives of these islands sell them to the Japanese for the best price possible
column73: and seek them carefully for this profit. However
column74: few are found now
column75: because of the assiduity with which the natives have applied themselves to that search. [287]

column1: The bar of the river of Manila, which is in the same bay, near the colony of Manila on one side and Tondo on the other, is not very deep because of certain sand shoals on it, which change their position at the time of the freshets and obstruct it. Consequently, although the water is deep enough for any vessel past the bar, still, unless they are fragatas, vireys, or other small vessels, they cannot pass the bar to enter the river. In respect to galleys, galliots, and the vessels from China, which draw but little water, they must enter empty, and at high tide, and by towing. Such vessels anchor in the bay outside the bar, and, for greater security enter the port of Cabit.There is another good port called Ybalon, [295] twenty leguas from the channel of the same island of Luzon, which is sheltered from the vendavals, and has a good entrance and anchorage. There the vessels that enter to escape the vendaval find shelter, and wait until the brisa returns, by which to go to Manila, eighty leguas away.On the coasts of Pangasinan, Ylocos, and Cagayan, there are some ports and bars, where ships can enter and remain, such as the harbor of Marihuma, [296] the port E1 Frayle ["the friar"], [297] that of Bolinao, the bar of Pangasinan, that of Bigan, the bar of Camalayuga, at the mouth of the Tajo River (which goes up two leguas to the chief settlement of Cagayan)--besides other rivers, bars, harbors, and shelters of less account for smaller vessels throughout the coasts of this island.Quite near this large island of Luzon, many other islands, large and small, are located; they are inhabited by the same natives as Luzon, who have gold placers, sowed fields, and their trading. Such are Marinduque, Tablas Island, Mazbate, Burias, Banton, Bantonillo, and others of less importance. The nearest of them to Manila is the island of Mindoro. It is more than eighty leguas long and about two hundred in circumference. It has many settlements of the same natives, and the side lying next the provinces of Balayan and Calilaya is so near and close to the island of Luzon, that it forms a strait which contains powerful currents and races, through which the ships going to and from Manila enter and leave. The winds and currents there are very strong. It is about one-half a legua wide. In that part is the chief town of this island of Mindoro. It has a port that is called El Varadero ["the place for laying up ships"] for large vessels. There are also other anchorages and bars throughout this island for smaller vessels; and many settlements and natives on all the coasts of this island. All of the settlements abound in rice, food, and gold-placers, and all kinds of game and timber. [298]The cape of Espiritu Santo, which is sighted by ships entering the Filipinas Islands on the way from Nueva España, is in an island called Tendaya, [299] in about thirteen degrees. Twenty leguas south after turning this cape of Espiritu Santo lie the island of Viri, and many others which are sighted. Through them an entrance opens to the island of Sebu by a strait called San Juanillo, which is formed by these islands. It is not very good or safe for the larger ships. But toward the north after leaving this course, one reaches the island of Capul, which forms a strait and channel of many currents and rough waves, through which the ships enter. Before reaching the strait there is a rock, or barren islet, called San Bernardino; this strait is formed by the coast of the island of Luzon and that of the island of Capul. Its channel is about one legua long and less wide.On leaving this strait, after having entered by it, three small islets form a triangle. They are called the islands of Naranjos ["Oranges"], and are lofty and inaccessible with steep rocks. Upon them ships are wont to be driven by the powerful currents, even though they try to escape them. These are not inhabited, but the others [Capul, Viri, etc.] are large islands containing many settlements of natives and all kinds of provisions and food.

South of this district lie the islands of Biçayas, or, as they are also called, Pintados. They are many in number, thickly populated with natives. Those of most renown are Leite, Ybabao, [300] Camar [Samar], Bohol, island of Negros, Sebu, Panay, Cuyo, and the Calamianes. All the natives of these islands, both men and women, are well-featured, of a good disposition, and of better nature, and more noble in their actions than the inhabitants of the islands of Luzon and its vicinity.They differ from them in their hair, which the men wear cut in a cue, like the ancient style in España. Their bodies are tattooed with many designs, but the face is not touched. [301] They wear large earrings of gold and ivory in their ears, and bracelets of the same; certain scarfs wrapped round the head, very showy, which resemble turbans, and knotted very gracefully and edged with gold. They wear also a loose collarless jacket with tight sleeves, whose skirts reach half way down the leg. These garments are fastened in front and are made of medriñaque and colored silks. They wear no shirts or drawers, but bahaques [i.e., breech-clouts] of many wrappings, which cover their privy parts, when they remove their skirts and jackets. The women are good-looking and graceful. They are very neat, and walk slowly. Their hair is black, long, and drawn into a knot on the head. Their robes are wrapped about the waist and fall downward. These are made of all colors, and they wear collarless jackets of the same material. Both men and women go naked and without any coverings, [302] and barefoot, and with many gold chains, earrings, and wrought bracelets.Their weapons consist of large knives curved like cutlasses, spears, and caraças [i.e., shields]. They employ the same kinds of boats as the inhabitants of Luzon. They have the same occupations, products, and means of gain as the inhabitants of all the other islands. These Visayans are a race less inclined to agriculture, and are skilful in navigation, and eager for war and raids for pillage and booty, which they call mangubas. [303] This means "to go out for plunder."Near the principal settlement of the island of Sebu, there is a fine port for all manner of vessels. It has a good entrance and furnishes shelter at all times. It has a good bottom and is an excellent anchorage. There are also other ports and bars of less importance and consideration, as in all these islands, for smaller vessels.Beyond it lie other islands, very pleasant and well populated, especially the island of Panay. Panay is a large island, more than one hundred leguas in circumference, containing many native settlements. [304] It produces considerable quantities of rice, palm-wine, and all manner of provisions. It has flourishing and wealthy settlements, on what is called the river of Panay. The chief one is Oton, which has a bar and port for galleys and ships, shipyards for building large ships, and a great amount of timber for their construction. There are many natives, who are masters of all kinds of shipbuilding. Near this island lies an islet eight leguas in circumference, which is densely populated by natives who are all carpenters. They are excellent workmen, and practice no other trade or occupation; and, without a single tree of any size on this whole islet, they practice this art with great ability. From there all the islands are furnished with workmen for carpentry. The island is called that of the Cagayanes.
After the island of Sebu follow immediately the island of Mindanao
column2: an island of more than three hundred leguas in circumference
column3: and Joló
column4: which is small. Lower down is the island of Borneo
column5: a very large island
column6: more than five hundred leguas in circumference. All of these islands are densely populated
column7: although that of Borneo is not subdued. Neither is that of Mindanao in entirety
column8: but only the river of Botuan
column9: Dapitan
column10: and the province and coast of Caragan.Below this island [Mindanao]
column11: before reaching that of Borneo
column12: lie the islands of the Calamianes. They are very numerous
column13: and consist of islands of various sizes
column14: which are densely inhabited with natives; they have some supply of provisions and engage in certain kinds of husbandry. However the most usual occupation is that of their navigations from island to island in pursuit of their trading and exchange
column15: and their fisheries; while those who live nearest the island of Borneo are wont to go on piratical raids and pillage the natives in other islands.The flow- and ebb-tides
column16: and the high and low tides among these islands are so diverse in them that they have no fixed rule
column17: either because of the powerful currents among these islands
column18: or by some other natural secret of the flux and reflux which the moon causes. No definite knowledge has been arrived at in this regard
column19: for although the tides are highest during the opposition of the moon
column20: and are higher in the month of March than throughout the rest of the year
column21: there is so great variation in the daily tides that it causes surprise. Some days there are two equal tides between day and night
column22: while other days there is but one. At other times the flow during the day is low
column23: and that of the night greater. They usually have no fixed hour
column24: for it may happen to be high-tide one day at noon
column25: while next day high-tide may be anticipated or postponed many hours. Or the tide of one day may be low
column26: and when a smaller one is expected for next day
column27: it may be much greater.The language of all the Pintados and Biçayas is one and the same
column28: by which they understand one another when talking
column29: or when writing with the letters and characters of their own which they possess. These resemble those of the Arabs. The common manner of writing among the natives is on leaves of trees
column30: and on bamboo bark. Throughout the islands the bamboo is abundant; it has huge and misshapen joints
column31: and lower part is a very thick and solid tree. [305]The language of Luzon and those islands in its vicinity differs widely from that of the Bicayas. [306] The language of the island of Luzon is not uniform
column32: for the Cagayans have one language and the Ylocos another. The Zambales have their own particular language
column33: while the Pampangos also have one different from the others. The inhabitants of the province of Manila
column34: the Tagáls
column35: have their own language
column36: which is very rich and copious. By means of it one can express elegantly whatever he wishes
column37: and in many modes and manners. It is not difficult
column38: either to learn or to pronounce.The natives throughout the islands can write excellently with certain characters
column39: almost like the Greek or Arabic. These characters are fifteen in all. Three are vowels
column40: which are used as are our five. The consonants number twelve
column41: and each and all of them combine with certain dots or commas
column42: and so signify whatever one wishes to write
column43: as fluently and easily as is done with our Spanish alphabet. The method of writing was on bamboo
column44: but is now on paper
column45: commencing the lines at the right and running to the left
column46: in the Arabic fashion. Almost all the natives
column47: both men and women
column48: write in this language. There are very few who do not write it excellently and correctly.

column1: This language of the province of Manila [i.e.
column2: the Tagál] extends throughout the province of Camarines
column3: and other islands not contiguous to Luzon. There is but little difference in that spoken in the various districts
column4: except that it is spoken more elegantly in some provinces than in others. [307]The edifices and houses of the natives of all these Filipinas Islands are built in a uniform manner
column5: as are their settlements; for they always build them on the shores of the sea
column6: between rivers and creeks. The natives generally gather in districts or settlements where they sow their rice
column7: and possess their palm trees
column8: nipa and banana groves
column9: and other trees
column10: and implements for their fishing and sailing. A small number inhabit the interior
column11: and are called tinguianes; they also seek sites on rivers and creeks
column12: on which they settle for the same reasons.The houses and dwellings of all these natives are universally set upon stakes and arigues [i.e.
column13: columns] high above the ground. Their rooms are small and the roofs low. They are built and tiled with wood and bamboos
column14: [308] and covered and roofed with nipa-palm leaves. Each house is separate
column15: and is not built adjoining another. In the lower part are enclosures made by stakes and bamboos
column16: where their fowls and cattle are reared
column17: and the rice pounded and cleaned. One ascends into the houses by means of ladders that can be drawn up
column18: which are made from two bamboos. Above are their open batalanes [galleries] used for household duties; the parents and [grown] children live together. There is little adornment and finery in the houses
column19: which are called bahandin. [309]Besides these houses
column20: which are those of the common people and those of less importance
column21: there are the chiefs' houses. They are built upon trees and thick arigues
column22: with many rooms and comforts. They are well constructed of timber and planks
column23: and are strong and large. They are furnished and supplied with all that is necessary
column24: and are much finer and more substantial than the others. They are roofed
column25: however
column26: as are the others
column27: with the palm-leaves called nipa. These keep out the water and the sun more than do shingles or tiles
column28: although the danger from fires is greater.The natives do not inhabit the lower part of their houses
column29: because they raise their fowls and cattle there
column30: and because of the damp and heat of the earth
column31: and the many rats
column32: which are enormous and destructive both in the houses and sowed fields; and because
column33: as their houses are generally built on the sea shore
column34: or on the banks of rivers and creeks
column35: the waters bathe the lower parts
column36: and the latter are consequently left open.There were no kings or lords throughout these islands who ruled over them as in the manner of our kingdoms and provinces; but in every island
column37: and in each province of it
column38: many chiefs were recognized by the natives themselves. Some were more powerful than others
column39: and each one had his followers and subjects
column40: by districts and families; and these obeyed and respected the chief. Some chiefs had friendship and communication with others
column41: and at times wars and quarrels. [310]These principalities and lordships were inherited in the male line and by succession of father and son and their descendants. If these were lacking
column42: then their brothers and collateral relatives succeeded. Their duty was to rule and govern their subjects and followers
column43: and to assist them in their interests and necessities. What the chiefs received from their followers was to be held by them in great veneration and respect; and they were served in their wars and voyages
column44: and in their tilling
column45: sowing
column46: fishing
column47: and the building of their houses. To these duties the natives attended very promptly
column48: whenever summoned by their chief. They also paid the chiefs tribute (which they called buiz)
column49: in varying quantities
column50: in the crops that they gathered. The descendants of such chiefs
column51: and their relatives
column52: even though they did not inherit the lordship
column53: were held in the same respect and consideration. Such were all regarded as nobles
column54: and as persons exempt from the services rendered by the others
column55: or the plebeians
column56: who were called timaguas. [311] The same right of nobility and chieftainship was preserved for the women
column57: just as for the men. When any of these chiefs was more courageous than others in war and upon other occasions
column58: such a one enjoyed more followers and men; and the others were under his leadership
column59: even if they were chiefs. These latter retained to themselves the lordship and particular government of their own following
column60: which is called barangai among them. They had datos and other special leaders [mandadores] who attended to the interests of the barangay.

column1: The superiority of these chiefs over those of their barangai was so great that they held the latter as subjects; they treated these well or ill
column2: and disposed of their persons
column3: their children
column4: and their possessions
column5: at will
column6: without any resistance
column7: or rendering account to anyone. For very slight annoyances and for slight occasions
column8: they were wont to kill and wound them
column9: and to enslave them. It has happened that the chiefs have made perpetual slaves of persons who have gone by them
column10: while bathing in the river
column11: or who have raised their eyes to look at them less respectfully and for other similar causes. [312]When some natives had suits or disputes with others over matters of property and interest
column12: or over personal injuries and wrongs received
column13: they appointed old men of the same district
column14: to try them
column15: the parties being present. If they had to present proofs
column16: they brought their witnesses there
column17: and the case was immediately judged according to what was found
column18: according to the usages of their ancestors on like occasions; and that sentence was observed and executed without any further objection or delay. [313]The natives' laws throughout the islands were made in the same manner
column19: and they followed the traditions and customs of their ancestors
column20: without anything being written. Some provinces had different customs than others in some respects. However
column21: they agreed in most
column22: and in all the islands generally the same usages were followed. [314]There are three conditions of persons among the natives of these islands
column23: and into which their government is divided: the chiefs
column24: of whom we have already treated; the timaguas
column25: who are equivalent to plebeians; and slaves
column26: those of both chiefs and timaguas.The slaves were of several classes. Some were for all kinds of work and slavery
column27: like those which we ourselves hold. Such are called saguiguilires; [315] they served inside the house
column28: as did likewise the children born of them. There are others who live in their own houses with their families
column29: outside the house of their lord; and come
column30: at the season
column31: to aid him in his sowings and harvests
column32: among his rowers when he embarks
column33: in the construction of his house when it is being built
column34: and to serve in his house when there are guests of distinction. These are bound to come to their lord's house whenever he summons them
column35: and to serve in these offices without any pay or stipend. These slaves are called namamahays
column36: [316] and their children and descendants are slaves of the same class. From these slaves--saguiguilirs and namamahays--are issue
column37: some of whom are whole slaves
column38: some of whom are half slaves
column39: and still others one-fourth slaves. It happens thus: if either the father or the mother was free
column40: and they had an only child
column41: he was half free and half slave. If they had more than one child
column42: they were divided as follows: the first follows the condition of the father
column43: free or slave; the second that of the mother. If there were an odd number of children
column44: the last was half free and half slave. Those who descended from these
column45: if children of a free mother or father
column46: were only one-fourth slaves
column47: because of being children of a free father or mother and of a half-slave. These half slaves or one-fourth slaves
column48: whether saguiguilirs or namamahays
column49: served their masters during every other moon; and in this respect so is such condition slavery.In the same way
column50: it may happen in divisions between heirs that a slave will fall to several
column51: and serves each one for the time that is due him. When the slave is not wholly slave
column52: but half or fourth
column53: he has the right
column54: because of that part that is free
column55: to compel his master to emancipate him for a just price. This price is appraised and regulated for persons according to the quality of their slavery
column56: whether it be saguiguilir or namamahay
column57: half slave or quarter slave. But
column58: if he is wholly slave
column59: the master cannot be compelled to ransom or emancipate him for any price.The usual price of a sanguiguilir slave among the natives is
column60: at most
column61: generally ten taes of good gold
column62: or eighty pesos; if he is namamahay
column63: half of that sum. The others are in the same proportion
column64: taking into consideration the person and his age.

column1: No fixed beginning can be assigned as the origin of these kinds of slavery among these natives
column2: because all the slaves are natives of the islands
column3: and not strangers. It is thought that they were made in their wars and quarrels. The most certain knowledge is that the most powerful made the others slaves
column4: and seized them for slight cause or occasion
column5: and many times for loans and usurious contracts which were current among them. The interest
column6: capital
column7: and debt
column8: increased so much with delay that the borrowers became slaves. Consequently all these slaveries have violent and unjust beginnings; and most of the suits among the natives are over these
column9: and they occupy the judges in the exterior court with them
column10: and their confessors in that of conscience. [317]These slaves comprise the greatest wealth and capital of the natives of these islands
column11: for they are very useful to them and necessary for the cultivation of their property. They are sold
column12: traded
column13: and exchanged among them
column14: just as any other mercantile article
column15: from one village to another
column16: from one province to another
column17: and likewise from one island to another. Therefore
column18: and to avoid so many suits as would occur if these slaveries were examined
column19: and their origin and source ascertained
column20: they are preserved and held as they were formerly.The marriages of these natives
column21: commonly and generally were
column22: and are: Chiefs with women chiefs; timaguas with those of that rank; and slaves with those of their own class. But sometimes these classes intermarry with one another. They considered one woman
column23: whom they married
column24: as the legitimate wife and the mistress of the house; and she was styled ynasaba. [318] Those whom they kept besides her they considered as friends. The children of the first were regarded as legitimate and whole heirs of their parents; the children of the others were not so regarded
column25: and were left something by assignment
column26: but they did not inherit.The dowry was furnished by the man
column27: being given by his parents. The wife furnished nothing for the marriage
column28: until she had inherited it from her parents. The solemnity of the marriage consisted in nothing more than the agreement between the parents and relatives of the contracting parties
column29: the payment of the dowry agreed upon to the father of the bride
column30: [319] and the assembling at the wife's parents' house of all the relatives to eat and drink until they would fall down. At night the man took the woman to his house and into his power
column31: and there she remained. These marriages were annulled and dissolved for slight cause
column32: with the examination and judgment of the relatives of both parties
column33: and of the old men
column34: who acted as mediators in the affairs. At such a time the man took the dowry (which they call vigadicaya)
column35: [320] unless it happened that they separated through the husband's fault; for then it was not returned to him
column36: and the wife's parents kept it. The property that they had acquired together was divided into halves
column37: and each one disposed of his own. If one made any profits in which the other did not have a share or participate
column38: he acquired it for himself alone.The Indians were adopted one by another
column39: in presence of the relatives. The adopted person gave and delivered all his actual possessions to the one who adopted him. Thereupon he remained in his house and care
column40: and had a right to inherit with the other children. [321]Adulteries were not punishable corporally. If the adulterer paid the aggrieved party the amount adjudged by the old men and agreed upon by them
column41: then the injury was pardoned
column42: and the husband was appeased and retained his honor. He would still live with his wife and there would be no further talk about the matter.In inheritances all the legitimate children inherited equally from their parents whatever property they had acquired. If there were any movable or landed property which they had received from their parents
column43: such went to the nearest relatives and the collateral side of that stock
column44: if there were no legitimate children by an ynasaba. This was the case either with or without a will. In the act of drawing a will
column45: there was no further ceremony than to have written it or to have stated it orally before acquaintances.

column1: If any chief was lord of a barangai
column2: then in that case
column3: the eldest son of an ynasaba succeeded him. If he died
column4: the second son succeeded. If there were no sons
column5: then the daughters succeeded in the same order. If there were no legitimate successors
column6: the succession went to the nearest relative belonging to the lineage and relationship of the chief who had been the last possessor of it.These children by a slave woman
column7: and those borne by a married woman
column8: were regarded as illegitimate
column9: and did not succeed to the inheritance with the other children
column10: neither were the parents obliged to leave them anything. Even if they were the sons of chiefs
column11: they did not succeed to the nobility or chieftainship of the parents
column12: nor to their privileges
column13: but they remained and were reckoned as plebeians and in the number and rank of the other timaguas.Loans with interest were very common and much practiced
column14: and the interest incurred was excessive. The debt doubled and increased all the time while payment was delayed
column15: until it stripped the debtor of all his possessions
column16: and he and his children
column17: when all their property was gone
column18: became slaves. [323]Their customary method of trading was by bartering one thing for another
column19: such as food
column20: cloth
column21: cattle
column22: fowls
column23: lands
column24: houses
column25: fields
column26: slaves
column27: fishing-grounds
column28: and palm-trees (both nipa and wild). Sometimes a price intervened
column29: which was paid in gold
column30: as agreed upon
column31: or in metal bells brought from China. These bells they regard as precious jewels; they resemble large pans and are very sonorous. [324] They play upon these at their feasts
column32: and carry them to the war in their boats instead of drums and other instruments. There are often delays and terms for certain payments
column33: and bondsmen who intervene and bind themselves
column34: but always with very usurious and excessive profits and interests.Crimes were punished by request of the aggrieved parties. Especially were thefts punished with greater severity
column35: the robbers being enslaved or sometimes put to death. [325] The same was true of insulting words
column36: especially when spoken to chiefs. They had among themselves many expressions and words which they regarded as the highest insult
column37: when said to men and women. These were pardoned less willingly and with greater difficulty than was personal violence
column38: such as wounding and assaulting. [326]Concubinage
column39: rape
column40: and incest
column41: were not regarded at all
column42: unless committed by a timagua on the person of a woman chief. It was a quite ordinary practice for a married man to have lived a long time in concubinage with the sister of his wife. Even before having communication with his wife he could have had access for a long time to his mother-in-law
column43: especially if the bride were very young
column44: and until she were of sufficient age. This was done in sight of all the relatives.Single men are called bagontaos
column45: [327] and girls of marriageable age
column46: dalagas. Both classes are people of little restraint
column47: and from early childhood they have communication with one another
column48: and mingle with facility and little secrecy
column49: and without this being regarded among the natives as a cause for anger. Neither do the parents
column50: brothers
column51: or relatives
column52: show any anger
column53: especially if there is any material interest in it
column54: and but little is sufficient with each and all.As long as these natives lived in their paganism
column55: it was not known that they had fallen into the abominable sin against nature. But after the Spaniards had entered their country
column56: through communication with them--and still more
column57: through that with the Sangleys
column58: who have come from China
column59: and are much given to that vice--it has been communicated to them somewhat
column60: both to men and to women. In this matter it has been necessary to take action.

column1: The natives of the islands of Pintados, especially the women, are very vicious and sensual. Their perverseness has discovered lascivious methods of communication between men and women; and there is one to which they are accustomed from their youth. The men skilfully make a hole in their virile member near its head, and insert therein a serpent's head, either of metal or ivory, and fasten it with a peg of the same material passed through the hole, so that it cannot become unfastened. With this device, they have communication with their wives, and are unable to withdraw until a long time after copulation. They are very fond of this and receive much pleasure from it, so that, although they shed a quantity of blood, and receive other harm, it is current among them. These devices are called sagras, and there are very few of them, because since they have become Christians, strenuous efforts are being made to do away with these, and not consent to their use; and consequently the practice has been checked in great part. [328]There were also men whose business was to ravish and take away virginity from young girls. These girls were taken to such men, and the latter were paid for ravishing them, for the natives considered it a hindrance and impediment if the girls were virgins when they married.In matters of religion, the natives proceeded more barbarously and with greater blindness than in all the rest. For besides being pagans, without any knowledge of the true God, they neither strove to discover Him by way of reason, nor had any fixed belief. The devil usually deceived them with a thousand errors and blindnesses. He appeared to them in various horrible and frightful forms, and as fierce animals, so that they feared him and trembled before him. They generally worshiped him, and made images of him in the said forms. These they kept in caves and private houses, where they offered them perfumes and odors, and food and fruit, calling them anitos. [329]Others worshiped the sun and the moon, and made feasts and drunken revels at the conjunction of those bodies. Some worshiped a yellow-colored bird that dwells in their woods, called batala. They generally worship and adore the crocodiles when they see them, by kneeling down and clasping their hands, because of the harm that they receive from those reptiles; they believe that by so doing the crocodiles will become appeased and leave them. Their oaths, execrations, and promises are all as above mentioned, namely, "May buhayan eat thee, if thou dost not speak truth, or fulfil what thou hast promised," and similar things.There were no temples throughout those islands, nor houses generally used for the worship of idols; but each person possessed and made in his house his own anitos, [330] without any fixed rite or ceremony. They had no priests or religious to attend to religious affairs, except certain old men and women called catalonas. These were experienced witches and sorcerers, who kept the other people deceived. The latter communicated to these sorcerers their desires and needs, and the catalonas told them innumerable extravagancies and lies. The catalonas uttered prayers and performed other ceremonies to the idols for the sick; and they believed in omens and superstitions, with which the devil inspired them, whereby they declared whether the patient would recover or die. Such were their cures and methods, and they used various kinds of divinations for all things. All this was with so little aid, apparatus, or foundation--which God permitted, so that the preaching of the holy gospel should find those of that region better prepared for it, and so that those natives would confess the truth more easily, and it would be less difficult to withdraw them from their darkness, and the errors in which the devil kept them for so many years. They never sacrificed human beings as is done in other kingdoms. They believed that there was a future life where those who had been brave and performed valiant feats would be rewarded; while those who had done evil would be punished. But they did not know how or where this would be. [331]

They buried their dead in their own houses, and kept their bodies and bones for a long time in chests. They venerated the skulls of the dead as if they were living and present. Their funeral rites did not consist of pomp or assemblages, beyond those of their own house--where, after bewailing the dead, all was changed into feasting and drunken revelry among all the relatives and friends. [332]A few years before the Spaniards subdued the island of Luzon, certain natives of the island of Borneo began to go thither to trade, especially to the settlement of Manila and Tondo; and the inhabitants of the one island intermarried with those of the other. These Borneans are Mahometans, and were already introducing their religion among the natives of Luzon, and were giving them instructions, ceremonies, and the form of observing their religion, by means of certain gazizes [333] whom they brought with them. Already a considerable number, and those the chiefest men, were commencing, although by piecemeal, to become Moros, and were being circumcised [334] and taking the names of Moros. Had the Spaniards' coming been delayed longer, that religion would have spread throughout the island, and even through the others, and it would have been difficult to extirpate it. The mercy of God checked it in time; for, because of being in so early stages, it was uprooted from the islands, and they were freed from it, that is, in all that the Spaniards have pacified, and that are under the government of the Filipinas. That religion has spread and extended very widely in the other islands outside of this government, so that now almost all of their natives are Mahometan Moros, and are ruled and instructed by their gaçizes and other morabitos; [335] these often come to preach to and teach them by way of the strait of Ma[la]ca and the Red Sea, through which they navigate to reach these islands.The arrival of the Spaniards in these Filipinas Islands, since the year one thousand five hundred and sixty-four, the pacification and conversion that has been made therein, their mode of governing, and the provisions of his Majesty during these years for their welfare, have caused innovations in many things, such as are usual to kingdoms and provinces that change their religion and sovereign. The foremost has been that, besides the name of Filipinas which all the islands took and received from the beginning of their conquest, they belong to a new kingdom and seigniory to which his Majesty, Filipo Second, our sovereign, gave the name of Nuevo Reyno de Castilla ["New Kingdom of Castilla"]. By his royal concession, he made the city of Manila capital of it, and gave to it as a special favor, among other things, a crowned coat-of-arms which was chosen and assigned by his royal person. This is an escutcheon divided across. In the upper part is a castle on a red field, and in the lower a lion of gold, crowned and rampant, holding a naked sword in its right paw. One-half of the body is in the form of a dolphin upon the waters of the sea, to signify that the Spaniards crossed the sea with their arms to conquer this kingdom for the crown of Castilla. [336]The city of Manila was founded by the adelantado Miguel Lopez de Legazpi, first governor of the Filipinas, in the island of Luzon. It occupies the same site where Rajamora had his settlement and fort--as has been related more at length--at the mouth of the river which empties into the bay, on a point between the river and the sea. The whole site was occupied by this new settlement, and Legazpi apportioned it to the Spaniards in equal building-lots. It was laid out with well-arranged streets and squares, straight and level. A sufficiently large main square [Plaza mayor] was left, fronting which were erected the cathedral church and municipal buildings. He left another square, that of arms [Plaza de armas], fronting which was built the fort, as well as the royal buildings. He gave sites for the monasteries, [337] hospital, and chapels which were to be built, as being a city which was to grow and increase continually--as already it has done; for, in the course of the time that has passed, that city has flourished as much as the best of all the cities in those regions.The city is completely surrounded with a stone wall, which is more than two and one-half varas wide, and in places more than three. It has small towers and traverses at intervals. [338] It has a fortress of hewn stone at the point that guards the bar and the river, with a ravelin close to the water, upon which are mounted some large pieces of artillery. This artillery commands the sea and river, while other pieces are mounted farther up to defend the bar, besides some other moderate-sized field-pieces and swivel-guns. These fortifications have their vaults for storing supplies and munitions, and a magazine for the powder, which is well guarded and situated in the inner part; and a copious well of fresh water. There are also quarters for the soldiers and artillerymen, and the house of the commandant [alcayde]. The city has been lately fortified on the land side at the Plaza de armas, where it is entered by a strong wall and two salient towers, defended with artillery, which command the wall and gate. This fortress is called Santiago, and has a company of thirty soldiers with their officers, and eight artillerymen who guard the gate and entrance by watches--all in charge of a commandant who lives inside, and has the guard and custody of the fort.
There is another fortress
column2: also of stone
column3: in the same wall
column4: within culverin range
column5: located at the end [339] of the curtain
column6: which extends along the shore of the bay. It is called Nuestra Señora de Guia
column7: and is a very large round tower. It has its own court
column8: well
column9: and quarters inside
column10: as well as the magazine
column11: and other rooms for work. It has a traverse extending to the beach
column12: on which are mounted a dozen large and moderate-sized pieces
column13: which command the bay and sweep the wall
column14: which extends along the shore to the gate and to the fort of Santiago. On the other side the fortress has a large salient tower
column15: mounted with four large pieces
column16: which command the shore ahead in the direction of the chapel of Nuestra Señora de Guia. The gate and entrance is within the city and is guarded by a company of twenty soldiers and their officers
column17: six artillerymen
column18: and one commandant and his lieutenant
column19: who live inside.On the land side
column20: where the wall extends
column21: there is a rampart called Sant Andres
column22: which mounts six pieces of artillery that command in all directions
column23: and some swivel-guns. Farther on is another traverse called San Gabriel
column24: opposite the parián of the Sangleys
column25: with a like amount of artillery. Both have some soldiers and an ordinary guard.The wall has a sufficient height
column26: and is furnished with battlements and turrets
column27: built in the modern style
column28: for its defense. It has a circuit of about one legua
column29: which can be made entirely on top. It has many broad steps of the same hewn stone
column30: at intervals inside. There are three principal city gates on the land side
column31: and many other posterns opening at convenient places on the river and beach
column32: for the service of the city. Each and all of them are locked before nightfall by the ordinary patrols. These carry the keys to the guard-room of the royal buildings. In the morning when day comes
column33: the patrols return with the keys and open the city. [340]The royal arsenals front on the Plaza de armas. In them are kept and guarded all the supplies of ammunition
column34: food
column35: rigging
column36: iron
column37: copper
column38: lead
column39: artillery
column40: arquebuses
column41: and other things belonging to the royal estate. They have their own officers and workmen
column42: and are placed in charge of the royal officials.The royal buildings are very beautiful and sightly
column43: and contain many rooms. They have many windows opening toward the sea and the Plaza de armas. They are all built of stone and have two courts
column44: with upper and lower galleries raised on stout pillars. The governor and president lives inside with his family. There is a hall for the royal Audiencia
column45: which is very large and stately; also a separate chapel
column46: a room for the royal seal
column47: [343] and offices for the scriveners of the Audiencia
column48: and the government. There are also other apartments for the royal treasury and the administration of the royal officials
column49: while a large porch opens on the street with two principal doors
column50: where the guardroom is located. There is one company of regular arquebusiers
column51: who come in daily with their banners to stand guard. Opposite
column52: on the other side of the street
column53: is another edifice for the royal treasury and those in charge of it. [344]On the same square is situated the cathedral church. It is built of hewn stone
column54: and has three naves
column55: and its main chapel
column56: and choir
column57: with high and low seats. The choir is shut in by railings
column58: and has its organ
column59: missal-stands
column60: and other necessary things. The cathedral has also its sacristan [346] and his apartments and offices.

column1: Within the city is the monastery of St. Augustine. It is very large and has many dormitories
column2: a refectory and kitchens. They are now completing a church
column3: which is one of the most sumptuous in those districts. This convent has generally fifty religious. [347]The monastery of St. Dominic is inside the walls. It contains about forty religious. It was built of stone
column4: and was very well constructed. It has a church
column5: house
column6: and all offices. It has lately been rebuilt
column7: and much better; for it was completely destroyed in the burning of the city in the year six hundred and three.The residence [colegio] of the Society of Jesus is established near the fortress of Nuestra Señora de Guia. It contains twenty religious of their order
column8: and is an excellent stone house and church. There they study Latin
column9: the arts
column10: and cases of conscience. Connected with them is a seminary and convictorio [348] for Spanish scholars
column11: with their rector. These students wear gowns of tawny-colored frieze with red facings. [349]In another part of the city stands a handsome house
column12: walled in
column13: with its stone church
column14: called San Andres and Santa Potenciana. It is a royal foundation
column15: and a rectoress lives there. It has a revolving entrance and a parlor
column16: and the rectoress has other confidential assistants; and there shelter is given to needy women and girls of the city
column17: in the form of religious retirement. Some of the girls leave the house to be married
column18: while others remain there permanently. It has its own house for work
column19: and its choir. His Majesty assists them with a portion of their maintenance; the rest is provided by their own industry and property. They have their own steward and their priest
column20: who administers the sacraments to them. [350]In another part is the royal hospital for Spaniards
column21: with its physician
column22: apothecary
column23: surgeons
column24: managers
column25: and servants. It and its church are built of stone; and it has its sick rooms and the bed service. In it all the Spaniards are treated. It is usually quite full; it is under the royal patronage. His Majesty provides the most necessary things for it. Three discalced religious of St. Francis act there as superintendents
column26: and they prove very advantageous for the corporal and spiritual relief of the sick. It was burned in the conflagration of the former year six hundred and three
column27: and is now being rebuilt.

column1: There is another charitable hospital in charge of the Confraternity of that name. It was founded in the city of Manila by the Confraternity of La Misericordia of Lisboa
column2: and by the other confraternities of India. [351] It has apostolic bulls for works of charity
column3: such as burying the dead
column4: supporting the modest poor
column5: marrying orphans
column6: and relieving many necessities. There the slaves of the city are treated
column7: and lodgings are likewise provided for poor women.Next to the monastery of St. Francis is located the hospital for natives
column8: [352] which is under royal patronage. It was founded with alms
column9: by a holy lay-brother of St. Francis
column10: one Fray Joan Clemente. A great many natives
column11: suffering from all diseases
column12: are treated there with great care and attention. It has a good edifice and workrooms built of stone. The discalced religious of St. Francis manage it; and three priests and four lay-brothers
column13: of exemplary life
column14: live there. These are the physicians
column15: surgeons
column16: and apothecaries of the hospital
column17: and are so skilful and useful
column18: that they cause many marvelous cures
column19: both in medicine and in surgery.The streets of the city are compactly built up with houses
column20: mostly of stone
column21: although some are of wood. Many are roofed with clay tiling
column22: and others with nipa. They are excellent edifices
column23: lofty and spacious
column24: and have large rooms and many windows
column25: and balconies
column26: with iron gratings
column27: that embellish them. More are daily being built and finished. There are about six hundred houses within the walls
column28: and a greater number
column29: built of wood
column30: in the suburbs; and all are the habitations and homes of Spaniards.The streets
column31: squares
column32: and churches are generally filled with people of all classes
column33: especially Spaniards--all
column34: both men and women
column35: clad and gorgeously adorned in silks. They wear many ornaments and all kinds of fine clothes
column36: because of the ease with which these are obtained. Consequently this is one of the settlements most highly praised
column37: by the foreigners who resort to it
column38: of all in the world
column39: both for the above reason
column40: and for the great provision and abundance of food and other necessaries for human life found there
column41: and sold at moderate prices.Manila has two drives for recreation. One is by land
column42: along the point called Nuestra Señora de Guia. It extends for about a legua along the shore
column43: and is very clean and level. Thence it passes through a native street and settlement
column44: called Bagunbayan
column45: to a chapel
column46: much frequented by the devout
column47: called Nuestra Señora de Guia
