column48: and continues for a goodly distance further to a monastery and mission-house of the Augustinians
column49: called Mahalat. [353]The other drive extends through one of the city gates to a native settlement
column50: called Laguio
column51: by which one may go to a chapel of San Anton
column52: and to a monastery and mission-house of discalced Franciscans
column53: a place of great devotion
column54: near the city
column55: called La Candelaria. [354]This city is the capital of the kingdom and the head of the government of all the islands. It is the metropolis of the other cities and settlements of the islands. In it reside the Audiencia and Chancillería of his Majesty
column56: and the governor and captain-general of the islands. [355]Manila has a city cabildo with two alcaldes-in-ordinary
column57: twelve perpetual regidors
column58: an alguaçil-mayor [i.e.
column59: chief constable]
column60: a royal standard-bearer
column61: the scrivener of the cabildo
column62: and other officials.

column1: The archbishop of the Filipinas Islands resides in this city. He has his metropolitan church
column2: and all the cathedral dignitaries--canons
column3: racioneros
column4: medias racioneros
column5: [356] chaplains
column6: and sacristans--and a music-choir
column7: who chant to the accompaniment of the organ and of flutes [ministriles]. The cathedral is quite ornate and well decorated
column8: and the Divine offices are celebrated there with the utmost gravity and ceremony. As suffragans the cathedral has three bishops--namely
column9: in the island of Sebu
column10: and in Cagayan and Camarines. [357]The vessels sailing annually to Nueva España with the merchandise and investments of all the islands are despatched from the city of Manila; and they return thither from Nueva España with the proceeds of this merchandise
column11: and the usual reënforcements.Several galleys are also stationed at Manila with their general and captains
column12: as well as other war-vessels
column13: of deep draft
column14: and smaller ones built like those used by the natives
column15: to attend to the needs of all the islands.The majority of the vessels from China
column16: Japon
column17: Maluco
column18: Borney
column19: Sian
column20: Malaca
column21: and India
column22: that come to the Filipinas with their merchandise and articles of trade
column23: gather in the bay and river of Manila. In that city they sell and trade for all the islands and their settlements.In the province [of Cagayán] of this same island of Luzon was founded the city of Segovia
column24: [359] during the term of Don Gonçalo Ronquillo
column25: the third governor. It has two hundred Spanish inhabitants who live in wooden houses on the shore of the Tajo River
column26: two leguas from the sea and port of Camalayuga. There is a stone fort near the city for the defense of it and of the river. This fort mounts some artillery
column27: and has its own commandant. Besides the inhabitants
column28: there are generally one hundred regular soldiers
column29: arquebusiers
column30: and their officers. They are all in charge and under command of the alcalde-mayor of the province
column31: who is its military commander.In that city is established a bishop and his church
column32: although at present the latter has no dignitaries or prebendaries. [360] There is a city cabildo consisting of two alcaldes
column33: six regidors
column34: and an alguacil-mayor. The city abounds in all kinds of food and refreshment at very cheap prices.The city of Caçeres was founded in the province of Camarines of the same island of Luzon
column35: during the term of Doctor Sande
column36: governor of the Filipinas. It has about one hundred Spanish inhabitants; and has its cabildo
column37: consisting of alcaldes
column38: regidors
column39: and officials. A bishop of that province is established there and has his church
column40: although without dignitaries or prebendaries. A monastery of discalced Franciscans is located there. The government and military affairs of that province are under one alcalde-mayor and war-captain
column41: who resides in Caçeres. The latter is a place abounding in and furnished with all kinds of provisions
column42: at very low rates. It is founded on the bank of a river
column43: four leguas inland from the sea
column44: and its houses are of wood.The fourth city is that called Santisimo Nombre de Jesus; it is located in the island of Sebu
column45: in the province of Bicayas or Pintados. It was the first Spanish settlement and was founded by the adelantado Miguel Lopez de Legazpi
column46: the first governor. It is a fine seaport
column47: whose water is very clear and deep
column48: and capable of holding many vessels. The city has an excellent stone fort
column49: which mounts a considerable quantity of artillery
column50: and which has its commandant and officers for the guard and defense of the port and of the city. It is sufficiently garrisoned with regulars
column51: and is under command of the alcalde-mayor
column52: the military commander of the province
column53: who lives in the city. The settlement contains about two hundred Spanish inhabitants who live in houses of wood. It has a cabildo
column54: consisting of two alcaldes-in-ordinary
column55: eight regidors
column56: and an alguacil-mayor and his officers. It has a bishop and his church
column57: like those of other cities of these islands
column58: without prebendaries. [361]

column1: The city is provided with food by
column2: and is a station for
column3: the ships going from Maluco to Manila. Through his Majesty's concession they keep there a deep-draft merchant vessel
column4: which generally leaves its port for Nueva España
column5: laden with the merchandise of the products gathered in those provinces. It has a monastery of Augustinian religious and a seminary of the Society of Jesus.The town of Arevalo was founded on the island of Oton [Panay]
column6: during the term of Don Gonçalo Ronquillo. [362] It contains about eighty Spanish inhabitants
column7: and is located close to the sea. It has a wooden fort
column8: which mounts some artillery
column9: and a monastery of the Order of St. Augustine; also a parish church
column10: with its own vicar and secular priest. This church belongs to the diocese of the Sebu bishopric.It has a cabildo
column11: consisting of alcaldes
column12: regidors
column13: and other officials. There is one alcalde-mayor and military leader in those provinces. The town is well supplied with all kinds of provisions
column14: sold at very low rates.The settlement of Villa Fernandina
column15: [363] which was founded in the province of the Ilocos on the island of Luzon
column16: is settled by Spaniards
column17: but very few of them remain there. It has a church
column18: with its own vicar and secular priest. Now no mention will be made of it
column19: on account of what has been said. The alcalde-mayor of the province resides there
column20: and the town is situated in the diocese of the Cagayan bishopric.From the earliest beginning of the conquest and pacification of the Filipinas Islands
column21: the preaching of the holy gospel therein and the conversion of the natives to our holy Catholic faith were undertaken. The first to set hand to this task were the religious of the Order of St. Augustine
column22: who went there with the adelantado Legazpi in the fleet of discovery
column23: and those of the same order who went afterward to labor in this work
column24: and toiled therein with great fervor and zeal. Thus
column25: finding the harvest in good season
column26: they gathered the first fruits of it
column27: and converted and baptized many infidels throughout the said islands. [364]Next to them in the fame of this conversion
column28: the discalced religious of the Order of St. Francis went to the islands by way of Nueva España; then those of the Order of St. Dominic
column29: and of the Society of Jesus. [365] Lastly
column30: the discalced Augustinian Recollects went. One and all
column31: after being established in the islands
column32: worked in the conversion and instruction of the natives. Consequently they have made--and there are now in all the islands--a great number of baptized natives
column33: besides many others in many parts
column34: who
column35: for want of laborers
column36: have been put off
column37: and are awaiting this blessing and priests to minister to them. Hitherto there have been but few missions in charge of secular priests
column38: as not many of these have gone to the islands; and as very few have been ordained there
column39: for lack of students.The Order of St. Augustine has many missions in the islands of Pintados and has established and occupied monasteries and various visitas. [366] In the island of Luzon
column40: they have those of the province of Ylocos
column41: some in Pangasinan
column42: and all those of La Pampanga--a large number of monasteries; while in the province of Manila and its vicinity they have others
column43: which are flourishing.The Society of Jesus has three large missions in the neighborhood of Manila
column44: which have many visitas. In the Pintados it has many others on the islands of Sebu
column45: Leite
column46: Ybabao
column47: Camar [Samar]
column48: Bohol
column49: and others near by. They have good men
column50: who are solicitous for the conversion of the natives.These four orders have produced many good results in the conversion of these islands
column51: as above stated; and in good sooth the people have taken firm hold of the faith
column52: as they are a people of so good understanding. They have recognized the errors of their paganism and the truths of the Christian religion; and they possess good and well-built churches and monasteries of wood with their reredoses and beautiful ornaments
column53: and all the utensils
column54: crosses
column55: candlesticks
column56: and chalices of silver and gold. Many devotions are offered
column57: and there are many confraternities. There is assiduity in taking the sacraments and in attendance on the Divine services; and the people are careful to entertain and support their religious (to whom they show great obedience and respect) by the many alms that they give them
column58: as well as by those that they give for the suffrages and the burial of their dead
column59: which they provide with all punctuality and liberality.

column1: At the same time that the religious undertook to teach the natives the precepts of religion
column2: they labored to instruct them in matters of their own improvement
column3: and established schools for the reading and writing of Spanish among the boys. They taught them to serve in the church
column4: to sing the plain-song
column5: and to the accompaniment of the organ; to play the flute
column6: to dance
column7: and to sing; and to play the harp
column8: guitar
column9: and other instruments. In this they show very great adaptability
column10: especially about Manila; where there are many fine choirs of chanters and musicians composed of natives
column11: who are skilful and have good voices. There are many dancers
column12: and musicians on the other instruments which solemnize and adorn the feasts of the most holy sacrament
column13: and many other feasts during the year. The native boys present dramas and comedies
column14: both in Spanish and in their own language
column15: very charmingly. This is due to the care and interest of the religious
column16: who work tirelessly for the natives' advancement. [367]In these islands there is no native province or settlement which resists conversion or does not desire it. But
column17: as above stated
column18: baptism has been postponed in some districts
column19: for lack of workers to remain with the people
column20: in order that they may not retrograde and return to their idolatries. In this work
column21: the best that is possible is done
column22: for the mission-fields are very large and extensive. In many districts the religious make use
column23: in their visitas
column24: of certain of the natives who are clever and well instructed
column25: so that these may teach the others to pray daily
column26: instruct them in other matters touching religion
column27: and see that they come to mass at the central missions; and in this way they succeed in preserving and maintaining their converts.Hitherto
column28: the orders who control these missions in virtue of the omnimodo and other apostolic concessions [368] have attended to the conversion of the natives
column29: administered the sacraments
column30: looked after the spiritual and temporal and ecclesiastical affairs of the natives
column31: and absolved them in cases of difficulty. But now that there are an archbishop and bishops
column32: this is being curtailed
column33: and the management of these affairs is being given to the bishops
column34: as the archbishop's vicars--although not to such an extent
column35: nor has the administration of these natives been placed in their charge
column36: in matters of justice
column37: and under the inspection and superintendence of the bishops
column38: as they have endeavored to obtain. [369]The governor and royal Audiencia of Manila attend to what it is advisable to provide and direct for the greatest accomplishment and advancement of this conversion
column39: and the administration of the natives and their missions--both by causing the encomenderos to assist the religious and churches
column40: in the encomiendas that they enjoy
column41: with the stipends and necessary expenses of the missions; and by furnishing from the royal revenues what pertains to it
column42: which is no less a sum. [370] They also ordain whatever else is required to be provided and remedied for the said missions and for the advancement of the natives. This also is attended to by the archbishop and the bishops in what pertains to them in their duty and charge as pastors.The Holy Office of the Inquisition
column43: residing in Mexico of Nueva España
column44: has its commissaries
column45: servants
column46: and helpers in Manila and in the bishoprics of the islands
column47: who attend to matters touching the Holy Office. They never fail to have plenty to do there because of the entrance of so many strangers into those districts. However
column48: this holy tribunal does not have jurisdiction of the causes pertaining to the natives
column49: as the latter are so recently converted.All these islands are subdued
column50: and are governed from Manila by means of alcaldes-mayor
column51: corregidors
column52: and lieutenants
column53: each of whom rules and administers justice in his own district and province. Appeals from their acts and sentences go to the royal Audiencia. The governor and captain-general provides what pertains to government and war.The chiefs
column54: who formerly held the other natives in subjection
column55: now have no power over them in the tyrannical manner of former days. This was not the least benefit received by these natives in having been freed from such servitude. However
column56: it is true that matters touching the slavery of former days have remained on the same footing as before. The king our sovereign has ordered by his decrees that the honors of the chiefs be preserved to them as such; and that the other natives recognize them and assist them with certain of the labors that they used to give when pagans. This is done with the lords and possessors of barangays
column57: and those belonging to such and such a barangay are under that chief's control. When he harvests his rice
column58: they go one day to help him; and the same if he builds a house
column59: or rebuilds one. This chief lord of a barangay collects tribute from his adherents
column60: and takes charge of these collections
column61: to pay them to the encomendero. [371]

column1: Besides the above
column2: each village has a governor [372] who is elected. He and his constables who are called vilangos [373] comprise the usual magistracy among the natives. The governor hears civil suits where a moderate sum is involved; in appeal
column3: the case goes to the corregidor or alcalde-mayor of the province. These governors are elected annually by the votes of all the married natives of such and such a village. The governor of Manila confirms the election
column4: and gives the title of governor to the one elected
column5: and orders him to take the residencia of the outgoing governor. [374] This governor
column6: in addition to the vilangos and scrivener (before whom he makes his acts in writing
column7: in the language of the natives of that province)
column8: [375] holds also the chiefs--lords of barangays
column9: and those who are not so--under his rule and government
column10: and
column11: for any special service
column12: such as collections of tributes
column13: and assignments of personal services
column14: as his datos and mandones. [376] They do not allow the chiefs to oppress the timaguas or slaves under their control.The same customs observed by these natives in their paganism
column15: are observed by them since they have become Christians
column16: in so far as they are not contrary to natural law
column17: especially as to their slavery
column18: successions
column19: inheritances
column20: adoptions
column21: wills
column22: and lawful trading. In their suits
column23: they always allege and prove the custom
column24: and are judged by it
column25: according to royal decrees to that effect. In other causes which do not involve their customs
column26: and in criminal cases
column27: the matter is determined by law as among Spaniards.All of these islands and their natives
column28: so far as they were pacified
column29: were apportioned into encomiendas from the beginning. To the royal crown were allotted those which were chief towns and ports
column30: and the dwellers of the cities and towns; and also other special encomiendas and villages in all the provinces
column31: for the necessities and expenses of the royal estate. All the rest was assigned to the conquerors and settlers who have served and labored for the conquest and pacification
column32: and in the war. This matter is in charge of the governor
column33: who takes into consideration the merits and services of the claimants. [377] In like manner the villages that become vacant are assigned. There are many very excellent encomiendas throughout the islands
column34: and they offer many profits
column35: both by the amount of their tributes and by the nature and value of what is paid as tribute. [378] The encomienda lasts
column36: according to the royal laws and decrees
column37: and by the regular order and manner of succession to them
column38: for two lives; but it may be extended to a third life
column39: by permission. After it becomes vacant
column40: it is again assigned and granted anew.The tributes paid to their encomenderos by the natives were assigned by the first governor
column41: Miguel Lopez de Legazpi
column42: in the provinces of Vicayas and Pintados
column43: and in the islands of Luzon and its vicinity; they were equal to the sum of eight reals annually for an entire tribute from each tributario. The natives were to pay it in their products--in gold
column44: cloth
column45: cotton
column46: rice
column47: bells
column48: fowls
column49: and whatever else they possessed or harvested. The fixed price and value of each article was assigned so that
column50: when the tribute was paid in any one of them
column51: or in all of them
column52: it should not exceed the value of the eight reals. So it has continued until now
column53: and the governors have increased the appraisements and values of the products at different times
column54: as they have deemed advisable.The encomenderos have made great profits in collecting in kind
column55: for
column56: after they acquired possession of the products
column57: they sold them at higher prices. By this they increased their incomes and the proceeds of their encomiendas considerably; until a few years ago his Majesty
column58: by petition of the religious and the pressure that they brought to bear on him in this matter
column59: ordered for this region that the natives should pay their tribute in whatever they wished--in kind or in money--without being compelled to do otherwise. Consequently
column60: when they should have paid their eight reals
column61: they would have fulfilled their obligation. Accordingly this rule was initiated; but experience demonstrates that
column62: although it seemed a merciful measure
column63: and one favorable to the natives
column64: it is doing them great injury. For
column65: since they naturally dislike to work
column66: they do not sow
column67: spin
column68: dig gold
column69: rear fowls
column70: or raise other food supplies
column71: as they did before
column72: when they had to pay the tribute in those articles. They easily obtain
column73: without so much work
column74: the peso of money which is the amount of their tribute. Consequently it follows that the natives have less capital and wealth
column75: because they do not work; and the country
column76: which was formerly very well provided and well-supplied with all products
column77: is now suffering want and deprivation of them. The owners of the encomiendas
column78: both those of his Majesty and those of private persons who possess them
column79: have sustained considerable loss and reduction in the value of the encomiendas.

column1: When Gomez Perez Dasmariñas was appointed governor of the Filipinas, he brought royal decrees ordering the formation of the camp in Manila, with an enrollment of four hundred paid soldiers, with their officers, galleys, and other military supplies, for the defense and security of the country. Before that time all the Spanish inhabitants had attended to that without any pay. Then an increase of two reals to each tributario over the eight reals was ordered. This was to be collected by the encomenderos at the same time when they collected the eight reals of the tribute, and was to be delivered and placed in the royal treasury. There this amount was to be entered on an account separate from that of the other revenue of his Majesty, and was to be applied in the following manner: one and one-half reals for the expenses of the said camp and war stores; and the remaining half real for the pay of the prebendaries of the Manila church, which his Majesty pays from his treasury, until such time as their tithes and incomes suffice for their sustenance. [379]These tributes are collected from all the natives, Christians and infidels, in their entirety--except that in those encomiendas without instruction the encomendero does not take the fourth part of the eight reals (which equals two reals) for himself, since that encomienda has no instruction or expenses for it; but he takes them and deposits them in Manila, in a fund called "the fourths." [380] The money obtained from this source is applied to and spent in hospitals for the natives, and in other works beneficial to them, at the option of the governor. As fast as the encomiendas are supplied with instruction and religious, the collection of these fourths and their expenditure in these special works cease.In most of the provinces no census has been taken, and the tributes are collected when due by the encomenderos and their collectors, through the chiefs of their encomiendas, by means of the lists and memoranda of former years. From them the names of the deceased and of those who have changed their residence are erased, and the names of those who have grown up, and of those who have recently moved into the encomienda, are added. When any shortage is perceived in the accounts, a new count is requested and made.The natives are free to move from one island to another, and from one province to another, and pay their tribute for that year in which they move and change their residence in the place to which they move; and to move from a Christian village that has instruction to another village possessing it. But, on the other hand, they may not move from a place having instruction to one without it, nor in the same village from one barangay to another, nor from one faction to another. In this respect, the necessary precautions are made by the government, and the necessary provisions by the Audiencia, so that this system may be kept, and so that all annoyances resulting from the moving of the settled natives of one place to another place may be avoided.Neither are the natives allowed to go out of their villages for trade, except by permission of the governor, or of his alcaldes-mayor and justices, or even of the religious, who most often have been embarrassed by this, because of the instruction. This is done so that the natives may not wander about aimlessly when there is no need of it, away from their homes and settlements.Those natives who possess slaves pay their tributes for them if the slaves are saguiguilirs. If the slaves are namamahays living outside their owners' houses, they pay their own tributes, inasmuch as they possess their own houses and means of gain.The Spaniards used to have slaves from these natives, whom they had bought from them, and others whom they obtained in certain expeditions during the conquest and pacification of the islands. This was stopped by a brief of his Holiness [381] and by royal decrees. Consequently, all of these slaves who were then in the possession of the Spanish, and who were natives of these islands, in whatever manner they had been acquired, were freed; and the Spaniards were forever prohibited from holding them as slaves, or from capturing them for any reason, or under pretext of war, or in any other manner. The service rendered by these natives is in return for pay and daily wages. The other slaves and captives that the Spaniards possess are Cafres and blacks brought by the Portuguese by way of India, and are held in slavery justifiably, in accordance with the provincial councils and the permissions of the prelates and justices of those districts.The natives of these islands have also their personal services, which they are obliged to render--in some parts more than in others--to the Spaniards. These are done in different ways, and are commonly called the polo. [382] For, where there are alcaldes-mayor and justices, they assign and distribute certain natives by the week for the service of their houses. They pay these servants a moderate wage, which generally amounts to one-fourth real per day, and rice for their food. The same is done by the religious for the mission, and for their monasteries and churches, and for their works, and for public works. [383]
The Indians also furnish rice
column2: and food of all kinds
column3: at the prices at which they are valued and sold among the natives. These prices are always very moderate. The datos
column4: vilangos
column5: and fiscals make the division
column6: collect
column7: and take these supplies from the natives; and in the same manner they supply their encomenderos when these go to make the collections.The greatest service rendered by these natives is on occasions of war
column8: when they act as rowers and crews for the vireys and vessels that go on the expeditions
column9: and as pioneers for any service that arises in the course of the war
column10: although their pay and wages are given them.In the same way natives are assigned and apportioned for the king's works
column11: such as the building of ships
column12: the cutting of wood
column13: the trade of making the rigging
column14: [384] the work in the artillery foundry
column15: and the service in the royal [385] magazines; and they are paid their stipend and daily wage.In other things pertaining to the service of the Spaniards and their expeditions
column16: works
column17: and any other service
column18: performed by the natives
column19: the service is voluntary
column20: and paid by mutual agreement; [386] for
column21: as hitherto
column22: the Spaniards have worked no mines
column23: nor have they given themselves to the gains to be derived from field labors
column24: there is no occasion for employing the natives in anything of that sort.Most of the Spaniards of the Filipinas Islands reside in the city of Manila
column25: the capital of the kingdom
column26: and where the chief trade and commerce is carried on. Some encomenderos live in provinces or districts adjacent to Manila
column27: while other Spaniards live in the cities of Segovia
column28: Caçeres
column29: Santisimo Nombre de Jesus (in Sebu)
column30: and in the town of Arevalo
column31: where they are settled
column32: and where most of them have their encomiendas.Spaniards may not go to the Indian villages
column33: [387] except for the collection of the tributes when they are due; and then only the alcaldes-mayor
column34: corregidors
column35: and justices. It is not permitted these to remain continually in one settlement of their district
column36: but they must visit as much of it as possible. They must change their residence and place of abode every four months to another chief village and settlement
column37: where all the natives may obtain the benefit of their presence; and so that the natives may receive as slight annoyance as possible in supporting them and in the ordinary service that they render them. [388]The governor makes appointments to all offices. When the term of office expires
column38: the royal Aurdiencia orders the residencia of each official to be taken
column39: and his case is decided in accordance therewith; and until the residencia is completed
column40: the incumbent cannot be appointed to any other duty or office. The governor also appoints commandants of forts
column41: companies
column42: and other military officials
column43: in all the cities
column44: towns
column45: and hamlets of the islands. [389]Certain offices of regidors and notaries have been sold by royal decree for one life. But the sale of these offices has been superseded
column46: as it is now considered that the price paid for them is of little consideration
column47: while the disadvantage of perpetuating the purchasers in office by this method is greater.Elections of alcaldes-in-ordinary for all the Spanish towns are held on New Year's day by the cabildo and magistracy. The residencias of these alcaldes-in-ordinary and their cabildos are ordered by his Majesty to be taken at the same time as that of the governor and captain-general of the islands is taken; and they give account of the administration of the revenues and the estates under their care. However
column48: the governor may take it before this
column49: every year
column50: or whenever he thinks it expedient and cause the balances of their accounts to be collected. With the governor's advice and permission the expenses desired by the towns are made.The city of Manila has sufficient public funds for certain years
column51: through the fines imposed by its judges; in its own particular possessions
column52: inside and outside the city; in the reweighing of the merchandise and the rents of all the shops and sites of the Sangleys in the parián; and in the monopoly on playing cards. All this was conceded to the city by his Majesty
column53: especially for the expenses of its fortification. [390] These revenues are spent for that purpose; for the salaries of its officials
column54: and those of the agents sent to España; and for the feasts of the city
column55: chief of which are St. Potenciana's day
column56: May nineteen
column57: when the Spaniards entered and seized the city
column58: and the day of St. Andrew
column59: November 30
column60: the date on which the pirate Limahon was conquered and driven from the city. On that day the city officials take out the municipal standard
column61: and to the sound of music go to vespers and mass at the church of San Andres
column62: where the entire city
column63: with the magistracy and cabildo and the royal Audiencia
column64: assemble with all solemnity. The above revenues are also used in receiving the governors at their first arrival in the country
column65: in the kings' marriage feasts
column66: and the births of princes
column67: and in the honors and funeral celebrations for the kings and princes who die. In all the above the greatest possible display is made.The other cities and settlements do not possess as yet so many sources of wealth or revenue
column68: or the occasions on which to spend them--although
column69: as far as possible
column70: they take part in them
column71: in all celebrations of the same kind.The Spaniards living in the islands are divided into five classes of people: namely
column72: prelates
column73: religious
column74: and ecclesiastical ministers
column75: both secular and regular; encomenderos
column76: settlers
column77: and conquerors; soldiers
column78: officers
column79: and officials of war (both on land and sea)
column80: and those for navigation; merchants
column82: and traders; and his Majesty's agents for government
column84: and administration of his royal revenue.

column1: The ecclesiastical prelates have already been stated
column2: and are as follows: The archbishop of Manila
column3: who resides in the city
column4: as metropolitan
column5: in charge of his cathedral church; he has a salary of four thousand pesos
column6: [391] which is paid from the royal treasury annually. Likewise the salaries paid to the holders of the dignidades
column7: [392] canonries
column8: and other prebends
column9: and those performing other services
column10: are paid in the same manner. They are all under royal patronage
column11: and are provided in accordance with the king's orders. The archbishop's office and jurisdiction consists of and extends to all
column12: both the spiritual and temporal
column13: that is ecclesiastic
column14: and to its management. [393]The bishop of the city of Santisimo Nombre de Jesus in Sibu
column15: that of Segovia in Cagayan
column16: and that of Caceres in Camarines
column17: have the same rights of jurisdiction and enjoy the same privileges in their dioceses
column18: since they are suffragans of the archbishop of Manila; appeal from their judgments is made to the latter
column19: and he summons and convokes them to his provincial councils whenever necessary. They receive each an annual salary of five hundred thousand maravedis for their support
column20: which is paid from the royal treasury of Manila
column21: besides their offerings and pontifical dues. All together it is quite sufficient for their support
column22: according to the convenience of things and the cheapness of the country. At present the bishops do not possess churches with prebendaries nor is any money set aside for that. [394]The regular prelates are the provincials of the four mendicant orders
column23: namely
column24: St. Dominic
column25: St. Augustine
column26: St. Francis
column27: the Society of Jesus
column28: and the discalced Augustinians. [395] Each prelate governs his own order and visits the houses. The orders have nearly all the missions to the natives under their charge
column29: in whatever pertains to the administration of the sacraments and conversion--by favor of
column30: and in accordance with
column31: their privileges and the apostolic bulls
column32: in which until now they have maintained themselves--and in what pertains to judicial matters
column33: as vicars of the bishops
column34: and through appointment and authorization of the latter. The discalced Augustinians as yet have no missions
column35: as they have but recently entered the islands.The monasteries are supported by certain special incomes that they possess and have acquired--especially those of the Augustinians and those of the Society--and by help and concessions granted by his Majesty. The Dominicans and Franciscans do not possess or allow incomes or properties; [396] and for them
column36: as for the other orders
column37: the principal source of revenue is in the alms
column38: offerings
column39: and aid given by the districts where they are established and where they have charge. This help is given by both Spaniards and natives
column40: very piously and generously. They are aided also by the stipend given them from the encomiendas for the instruction that they give there. Consequently the religious of the orders live well and with the comfort necessary.The first encomenderos
column41: conquerors
column42: and settlers of the islands
column43: and their issue
column44: are honorably supported by the products of their encomiendas
column45: and by certain means of gain and trading interests that they possess
column46: as do the rest of the people. There are a great number of them
column47: each one of whom lives and possesses his house in the city and settlement of Spaniards in whose province he has his encomienda. This they do in order not to abandon their encomiendas
column48: and thus they are nearer the latter for their needs and for collections.The soldiers and officers of war and of naval expeditions formerly consisted of all the dwellers and inhabitants of the islands
column49: who rendered military service without any pay or salary. They went on all the expeditions and pacifications that arose
column50: and guarded the forts and presidios
column51: and cities and settlements. This was their principal exercise and occupation. They were rewarded by the governor
column52: who provided them with encomiendas
column53: offices
column54: and profits of the country according to their merits and services. [397]At that time the soldiers of the islands were the best in the Indias. They were very skilful and well-disciplined by both land and sea
column55: and were esteemed and respected by all those nations. They gloried in their arms
column56: and in acquitting themselves valiantly.

column1: Afterward
column2: when Gomez Perez Das Mariñas entered upon the government of the Filipinas
column3: he founded the regular camp of four hundred soldiers: the arquebusiers
column4: with pay of six pesos per month; the musketeers
column5: with eight pesos; six captains
column6: with annual pay of four hundred and twenty pesos apiece; their alféreces
column7: sergeants
column8: corporals
column9: standard-bearers
column10: and drummers
column11: with pay in proportion to their duties; one master-of-camp
column12: with annual pay of one thousand four hundred pesos; one sargento-mayor with captain's pay; one adjutant of the sargento-mayor and field-captain
column13: with monthly pay of ten pesos; two castellans; commandants of the two fortresses of Manila
column14: with four hundred pesos apiece annually; their lieutenants; squads of soldiers and artillerymen; one general of galleys
column15: with annual pay of eight hundred pesos; each galley one captain
column16: with annual pay of three hundred pesos; their boatswains
column17: boatswains' mates
column18: coxswains
column19: alguacils of the galleys
column20: soldiers
column21: artillerymen
column22: master-carpenters
column23: riggers
column24: sailors
column25: conscripts
column26: [398] galley-crews of Spanish
column27: Sangley
column28: and native convicts
column29: condemned for crimes; and
column30: when there is lack of convicts
column31: good rowers are obtained from the natives for pay
column32: for the period of the expedition and the occasion of the voyage. [399]In the vessels and fleets of large vessels for the Nueva España line
column33: the ships that are sent carry a general
column34: admiral
column35: masters
column36: boatswains
column37: commissaries
column38: stewards
column39: alguacils
column40: sergeants of marine artillery [condestables]
column41: artillerymen
column42: sailors
column43: pilots and their assistants
column44: common seamen
column45: carpenters
column46: calkers
column47: and coopers
column48: all in his Majesty's pay
column49: on the account of Nueva España
column50: from whose royal treasury they are paid. All that is necessary for this navigation is supplied there. Their provisions and appointments are made by the viceroy; and this has hitherto pertained to him
column51: even though the ships may have been constructed in the Filipinas. They sail thence with their cargo of merchandise for Nueva España
column52: and return thence to the Filipinas with the reënforcements of soldiers and supplies
column53: and whatever else is necessary for the camp
column54: besides passengers and religious
column55: and the money proceeding from the investments and merchandise. [400]After the establishment of a regular camp for guard and expeditions
column56: the other inhabitants
column57: dwellers
column58: and residents were enrolled without pay under the banners of six captains of the Filipinas
column59: for special occasions requiring the defense of the city. But they were relieved of all other duties pertaining to the troops
column60: unless they should offer of their own accord to go upon any expedition
column61: or volunteer for any special occasion
column62: in order to acquire merits and benefits
column63: so that they may be given encomiendas that become vacant
column64: and offices
column65: and the means of profit of the country. They are not compelled or obliged to do this
column66: unless they are encomenderos. Consequently all have given themselves to trading
column67: as there is no other occupation
column68: but they are not unmindful of military service.His Majesty prohibits all who are in his pay in the military forces of the islands from engaging in commerce; and orders the governor not to allow this
column69: or permit them to export goods to Nueva España. If the governors would observe that order
column70: it would not be amiss. [401]The merchants and business men form the bulk of the residents of the islands
column71: because of the great amount of merchandise brought there--outside of native products--from China
column72: Japon
column73: Maluco
column74: Malaca
column75: Sian
column76: Camboja
column77: Borneo
column78: and other districts. They invest in this merchandise and export it annually in the vessels that sail to Nueva España
column79: and at times to Japon
column80: where great profits are made from raw silk. Thence on the return to Manila are brought the proceeds
column81: which hitherto have resulted in large and splendid profits.Through the very great increase of this trade--which was harmful and prejudicial to the Spanish merchants who shipped goods to Peru and Nueva España
column82: and to the royal duties collected on the shipments from España--and through the business men of Mexico and Peru having become greedy of trade and commerce with the Filipinas
column83: by means of their agents and factors
column84: so that the trade with España was ceasing in great measure
column85: and the merchants were sending to the Filipinas for their investments great consignments of silver
column86: which by that means flowed yearly from his Majesty's kingdoms
column87: to fall into the possession of infidels: all persons of Nueva España and Peru were prohibited from trading and engaging in commerce in the Filipinas
column88: and from taking the Chinese merchandise to those regions. [402] Permission was given to the inhabitants and residents of the Filipinas that they alone might trade in the said merchandise
column89: and export it. They are to take these goods themselves
column90: or send them with persons who belong to the islands
column91: so that they may sell them. From the proceeds of the said merchandise
column92: they may not carry to the Filipinas more than five hundred thousand pesos each year. [403]A considerable number of somas and junks (which are large vessels) generally come from Great China to Manila
column93: laden with merchandise. Every year thirty or even forty ships are wont to come
column94: and although they do not come together
column95: in the form of a trading and war fleet
column96: still they do come in groups with the monsoon and settled weather
column97: which is generally at the new moon in March. They belong to the provinces of Canton
column100: and sail from those provinces. They make their voyage to the city of Manila in fifteen or twenty days
column103: before the vendavals set in--the end of May and a few days of June--in order not to endanger their voyage.These vessels come laden with merchandise
column104: and bring wealthy merchants who own the ships
column105: and servants and factors of other merchants who remain in China. They leave China with the permission and license of the Chinese viceroys and mandarins. The merchandise that they generally bring and sell to the Spaniards consists of raw silk in bundles
column106: of the fineness of two strands [dos cabeças]
column107: and other silk of poorer quality; fine untwisted silk
column109: wound in small skeins; quantities of velvets
column111: and some embroidered in all sorts of figures
column113: and fashions--others with body of gold
column114: and embroidered with gold; woven stuffs and brocades
column115: of gold and silver upon silk of various colors and patterns; quantities of gold and silver thread in skeins over thread and silk--but the glitter of all the gold and silver is false
column121: [404] and other cloths of all colors
column122: some finer and better than others; a quantity of linen made from grass
column123: called lençesuelo [handkerchief]; [405] and white cotton cloth of different kinds and qualities
column124: for all uses. They also bring musk
column129: and tapestries of embroidered velvet; damask and gorvaran of different shades; tablecloths
column131: and carpets; horse-trappings of the same stuff
column132: and embroidered with glass beads and seed-pearls; also some pearls and rubies
column135: and other copper and cast-iron pots; quantities of all sorts of nails
column137: tin and lead; saltpetre and gunpowder. They supply the Spaniards with wheat flour; preserves made of orange
column143: and other fruits of China; salt pork and other salt meats; live fowls of good breed
column144: and very fine capons; quantities of green fruit
column145: oranges of all kinds; excellent chestnuts
column149: a delicious fruit); quantities of fine thread of all kinds
column151: and knick-knacks; little boxes and writing-cases; beds
column155: painted in many figures and patterns. They bring domestic buffaloes; geese that resemble swans; horses
column156: some mules and asses; even caged birds
column159: and they make them play innumerable tricks. The Chinese furnish numberless other gewgaws and ornaments of little value and worth
column160: which are esteemed among the Spaniards; besides a quantity of fine crockery of all kinds; canganes
column162: and black and blue robes; tacley
column163: which are beads of all kinds; strings of cornelians
column164: and other beads and precious stones of all colors; pepper and other spices; and rarities--which
column165: did I refer to them all
column167: nor have sufficient paper for it.

column1: As soon as the ship reaches the mouth of the bay of Manila
column2: the watchman stationed at the island of Miraveles goes out to it in a light vessel. Having examined the ship
column3: he puts a guard of two or three soldiers on it
column4: so that it may anchor upon the bar
column5: near the city
column6: and to see that no one shall disembark from the vessel
column7: or anyone enter it from outside
column8: until the vessel has been inspected. By the signal made with fire by the watchman from the said island
column9: and the advice that he sends in all haste to the city--of what ship it is
column10: whence it has come
column11: what merchandise and people it brings--before the vessel has finished anchoring
column12: the governor and the city generally know all about it. [409]When the vessel has arrived and anchored
column13: the royal officials go to inspect it and the register of the merchandise aboard it. At the same time the valuation of the cargo is made according to law
column14: of what it is worth in Manila; for the vessel immediately pays three per cent on everything to his Majesty. [410] After the register has been inspected and the valuation made
column15: then the merchandise is immediately unloaded by another official into champans
column16: and taken to the Parián
column17: or to other houses and magazines
column18: outside of the city. There the goods are freely sold.No Spaniard
column19: Sangley
column20: or other person is allowed to go to the ship to buy or trade merchandise
column21: food
column22: or anything else. Neither is it allowed
column23: when the merchandise is ashore
column24: to take it from them or buy it with force and violence; but the trade must be free
column25: and the Sangleys can do what they like with their property.The ordinary price of the silks (both raw and woven) and the cloths--which form the bulk of the cargo--is settled leisurely
column26: and by persons who understand it
column27: both on the part of the Spaniards and that of the Sangleys. The purchase price is paid in silver and reals
column28: for the Sangleys do not want gold
column29: or any other articles
column30: and will not take other things to China. All the trading must be completed by the end of the month of May
column31: or thereabout
column32: in order that the Sangleys may return and the Spaniards have the goods ready to lade upon the vessels that go to Nueva España by the end of June. However
column33: the larger dealers and those who have most money usually do their trading after that time
column34: at lower rates
column35: and keep the merchandise until the following year. Certain Sangleys remain in Manila with a portion of their merchandise for the same purpose
column36: when they have not had a good sale for it
column37: in order to go on selling it more leisurely. The Sangleys are very skilful and intelligent traders
column38: and of great coolness and moderation
column39: in order to carry on their business better. They are ready to trust and accommodate freely whoever they know treats them fairly
column40: and does not fail in his payments to them when these are due. On the other hand
column41: as they are a people without religion or conscience
column42: and so greedy
column43: they commit innumerable frauds and deceits in their merchandise. The purchaser must watch them very closely
column44: and know them
column45: in order not to be cheated by them. The purchasers
column46: however
column47: acquit themselves by their poor payments and the debts that they incur; and both sides generally keep the judges and Audiencia quite busy.Some Japanese and Portuguese merchantmen also come every year from the port of Nangasaque in Japon
column48: at the end of October with the north winds
column49: and at the end of March. They enter and anchor at Manila in the same way. The bulk of their cargo is excellent wheat-flour for the provisioning of Manila
column50: and highly prized salt meats. They also bring some fine woven silk goods of mixed colors; beautiful and finely-decorated screens done in oil and gilt; all kinds of cutlery; many suits of armor
column51: spears
column52: catans
column53: and other weapons
column54: all finely wrought; writing-cases
column55: boxes and small cases of wood
column56: japanned and curiously marked; other pretty gewgaws; excellent fresh pears; barrels and casks of good salt tunny; cages of sweet-voiced larks
column57: called fimbaros; and other trifles. In this trading
column58: some purchases are also made
column59: without royal duties being collected from those vessels. The bulk of the merchandise is used in the country
column60: but some goods are exported to Nueva España. The price is generally paid in reals
column61: although they are not so greedy for them as the Chinese
column62: for there is silver in Japon. They generally bring a quantity of it as merchandise in plates
column63: and it is sold at moderate rates.These vessels return to Japon at the season of the vendavals
column64: during the months of June and July. They carry from Manila their purchases
column65: which are composed of raw Chinese silk
column66: gold
column67: deerskin
column68: and brazil-wood for their dyes. They take honey
column69: manufactured wax
column70: palm and Castilian wine
column71: civet-cats
column72: large tibors in which to store their tea
column73: glass
column74: cloth
column75: and other curiosities from España.

column1: Some Portuguese vessels sail to Manila annually during the monsoon of the vendavals
column2: from Maluco
column3: Malaca
column4: and India. They take merchandise consisting of spices--cloves
column5: cinnamon
column6: and pepper; slaves
column7: both blacks and Cafres; cotton cloth of all sorts
column8: fine muslins [caniquies]
column9: linens
column10: gauzes
column11: rambuties
column12: and other delicate and precious cloths; amber
column13: and ivory; cloths edged with pita
column14: [411] for use as bed-covers; hangings
column15: and rich counterpanes from Vengala [Bengal]
column16: Cochin
column17: and other countries; many gilt articles and curiosities; jewels of diamonds
column18: rubies
column19: sapphires
column20: topazes
column21: balas-rubies
column22: and other precious stones
column23: both set and loose; many trinkets and ornaments from India; wine
column24: raisins
column25: and almonds; delicious preserves
column26: and other fruits brought from Portugal and prepared in Goa; carpets and tapestries from Persia and Turquia
column27: made of fine silks and wools; beds
column28: writing-cases
column29: parlor-chairs
column30: and other finely-gilded furniture
column31: made in Macao; needle-work in colors and in white
column32: of chain-lace and royal point lace
column33: and other fancy-work of great beauty and perfection. Purchases of all the above are made in Manila
column34: and paid in reals and gold. The vessels return in January with the brisas
column35: which is their favorable monsoon. They carry to Maluco provisions of rice and wine
column36: crockery-ware
column37: and other wares needed there; while to Malaca they take only the gold or money
column38: besides a few special trinkets and curiosities from España
column39: and emeralds. The royal duties are not collected from these vessels.A few smaller vessels also sail from Borneo
column40: during the vendavals. They belong to the natives of that island
column41: and return during the first part of the brisas. They enter the river of Manila and sell their cargoes in their vessels. These consist of fine and well-made palm-mats
column42: a few slaves for the natives
column43: sago--a certain food of theirs prepared from the pith of palms--and tibors; large and small jars
column44: glazed black and very fine
column45: which are of great service and use; and excellent camphor
column46: which is produced on that island. Although beautiful diamonds are found on the opposite coast
column47: they are not taken to Manila by those vessels
column48: for the Portuguese of Malaca trade for them on that coast. These articles from Borneo are bought more largely by the natives than by the Spaniards. The articles taken back by the Borneans are provisions of wine and rice
column49: cotton cloth
column50: and other wares of the islands
column51: which are wanting in Borneo.Very seldom a few vessels sail to Manila from Sian and Camboja. They carry some benzoin
column52: pepper
column53: ivory
column54: and cotton cloth; rubies and sapphires
column55: badly cut and set; a few slaves; rhinoceros horns
column56: and the hides
column57: hoofs
column58: and teeth of this animal; and other goods. In return they take the wares found in Manila. Their coming and return is between the brisas and the vendavals
column59: during the months of April
column60: May
column61: and June.In these classes of merchandise
column62: and in the products of the islands--namely
column63: gold
column64: cotton cloth
column65: mendriñaque
column66: and cakes of white and yellow wax--do the Spaniards effect their purchases
column67: investments
column68: and exports for Nueva España. They make these as is most suitable for each person
column69: and lade them on the vessels that are to make the voyage. They value and register these goods
column70: for they pay into the royal treasury of Manila
column71: before the voyage
column72: the two per cent royal duties on exports
column73: besides the freight charges of the vessel
column74: which amount to forty Castilian ducados [412] per tonelada. This latter is paid at the port of Acapulco in Nueva España
column75: into the royal treasury of the said port
column76: in addition to the ten per cent duties for entrance and first sale in Nueva España. [413]Inasmuch as the ships which are despatched with the said merchandise are at his Majesty's account
column77: and other ships cannot be sent
column78: there is generally too small a place in the cargo for all the purchases. For that reason the governor divides the cargo-room among all the shippers
column79: according to their wealth and merits
column80: after they have been examined by intelligent men
column81: appointed for that purpose. Consequently every man knows from his share how much he can export
column82: and only that amount is received in the vessel; and careful and exact account is taken of it. Trustworthy persons are appointed who are present at the lading; and space is left for the provisions and passengers that are to go in the vessels. When the ships are laden and ready to sail
column83: they are delivered to the general and the officials who have them in charge. Then they start on their voyage at the end of the month of June
column84: with the first vendavals.This trade and commerce is so great and profitable
column85: and easy to control--for it only lasts three months in the year
column86: from the time of the arrival of the ships with their merchandise
column87: until those vessels that go to Nueva España take that merchandise--that the Spaniards do not apply themselves to
column90: there is no husbandry or field-labor worthy of consideration. Neither do the Spaniards work the gold mines or placers
column91: which are numerous. They do not engage in many other industries that they could turn to with great profit
column92: if the Chinese trade should fail them. That trade has been very hurtful and prejudicial in this respect
column93: as well as for the occupations and farm industries in which the natives used to engage. Now the latter are abandoning and forgetting those labors. Besides
column94: there is the great harm and loss resulting from the immense amount of silver that passes annually by this way [of the trade]
column98: return into the possession of the Spaniards.

column1: His Majesty's agents for the government and justice
column2: and the royal officials for the management of his Majesty's revenue
column3: are as follows: First
column4: the governor and captain-general of all the islands
column5: who is at the same time president of the royal Audiencia of Manila. He has a salary of eight thousand pesos de minas per year for all his offices. [414] He possesses his own body-guard of twelve halberdiers
column6: whose captain receives three hundred pesos per year. The governor alone provides and regulates all that pertains to war and government
column7: with the advice of the auditors of the Audiencia in difficult matters. He tries in the first instance the criminal cases of the regular soldiers
column8: and any appeals from his decisions go to the Audiencia. [415] The governor appoints many alcaldes-mayor
column9: corregidors
column10: deputies
column11: and other magistrates
column12: throughout the islands and their provinces
column13: for carrying on the government and justice
column14: and for military matters. These appointments are made before a government chief scrivener appointed by his Majesty
column15: who helps the governor.The governor likewise takes part with the royal Audiencia
column16: as its president
column17: in whatever pertains to its duties. The Audiencia consists of four auditors and one fiscal--each of whom receives an annual salary of two thousand pesos de minas [416]--one reporter
column18: one court scrivener
column19: one alguacil-mayor
column20: with his assistants
column21: one governor of the prison of the court
column22: one chancellor
column23: one registrar
column24: two bailiffs
column25: one chaplain and sacristan
column26: one executioner
column27: attorneys
column28: and receivers. The Audiencia tries all causes
column29: civil and criminal
column30: taken to it from all the provinces of its district. [417] These include the Filipinas Islands and the mainland of China
column31: already discovered or to be discovered. The Audiencia has the same authority as the chancillerías of Valladolid and Granada in España. At the same time
column32: the Audiencia provides whatever is advisable for the proper and systematic management of the royal exchequer.His Majesty's revenues in the Filipinas Islands are in charge of and their tribunal consists of three royal officials. They are appointed by his Majesty
column33: and consist of a factor
column34: an accountant
column35: and a treasurer. They each receive an annual salary of five hundred and ten thousand maravedis. They have their clerk of mines
column36: and registrars of the royal revenues
column37: and their executive and other officials
column38: all of whom reside in Manila. From that city they manage and attend to everything pertaining to the royal revenues throughout the islands.His Majesty has a number of encomiendas apportioned to his royal crown throughout the provinces of the Filipinas Islands. The tributes of those encomiendas are collected for his royal treasury by his royal officials and the collectors engaged for that purpose by the royal officials. From year to year these amount to thirty thousand pesos
column39: after deducting costs and expenses. They collect
column40: from one year to another
column41: eight thousand pesos in tributes from the Sangleys--both Christians and infidels. [418]They also collect the fifth of all gold dug in the islands. By special concession for a limited period
column42: the tenth is collected instead of the fifth. There is a declaration concerning it
column43: to the effect that the natives shall pay no fifths or other duties on the jewels and gold inherited by them from their ancestors before his Majesty owned the country. Sufficient measures have been taken for the clear understanding of this concession and its investigation
column44: for that on which the tenth has once been paid
column45: and the steps to be taken in the matter. From one year to another they collect ten thousand pesos from these fifths
column46: for much is concealed. [419]The assignment of two reals from each tributario inures to the royal treasury and is paid into it
column47: for the pay of the soldiers and the stipend of the prebendaries. These are collected from the encomenderos
column48: in proportion to
column49: and on the account of
column50: their tributes
column51: and amount annually to thirty-four thousand pesos.

column1: The two per cent duties paid by the Spaniards for exporting merchandise to Nueva España amount annually to twenty thousand pesos. On the merchandise and money sent from Nueva España to the Filipinas
column2: result eight thousand pesos more. Consequently
column3: in these things and in other dues of less importance that belong to the royal treasury
column4: his Majesty receives about one hundred and fifty thousand pesos
column5: or thereabout
column6: annually in the Filipinas. [421]Inasmuch as this amount does not suffice for the expenses that are incurred
column7: the royal treasury of Nueva España sends annually to that of the Filipinas
column8: in addition to the above revenues
column9: some assistance in money--a greater or less sum
column10: as necessity requires. For his Majesty has thus provided for it from the proceeds of the ten per cent duties on the Chinese merchandise that are collected at the port of Acapulco in Nueva España. This assistance is given into the keeping of the royal officials in Manila
column11: and they take charge of it
column12: with the rest of the revenues that they manage and collect.From all this gross sum of his Majesty's revenue
column13: the salaries of the governor and royal Audiencia are paid
column14: as well as the stipends of prelates and ecclesiastical prebendaries
column15: the salaries of the magistrates
column16: and of the royal officials and their assistants; the pay of all the military officers and regular soldiers; his Majesty's share of the stipends for instruction
column17: and the building of churches and their ornaments; the concessions and gratifications that he has allowed to certain monasteries
column18: and private persons; the building of large vessels for the navigation to Nueva España
column19: and of galleys and other vessels for the defense of the islands; expenses for gunpowder and ammunition; the casting of artillery
column20: and its care; the expense arising for expeditions and individual undertakings in the islands
column21: and in their defense; that of navigations to
column22: and negotiations with
column23: the kingdoms in their vicinity
column24: which are quite common and necessary. Consequently
column25: since his Majesty's revenues in these islands are so limited
column26: and his expenses so great
column27: the royal treasury falls short
column28: and suffers poverty and need. [422]The proceeds from the ten per cent duties and the freight charges of the ships
column29: which are collected at Acapulco in Nueva España
column30: on the merchandise sent there from the Filipinas
column31: although considerable
column32: are also not always sufficient for the expenses incurred in Nueva España with the ships
column33: soldiers
column34: ammunition
column35: and other supplies sent annually to the Filipinas. These expenses are generally greatly in excess of those duties
column36: and the amount is made up from the royal treasury of Mexico. Consequently
column37: the king our sovereign derives as yet no profit from any revenues of the Filipinas
column38: but rather an expenditure
column39: by no means small
column40: from his revenues in Nueva España. He sustains the Filipinas only for the christianization and conversion of the natives
column41: and for the hopes of greater fruits in other kingdoms and provinces of Asia
column42: which are expected through this gateway
column43: at God's good pleasure.In the city of Manila
column44: and in all those Spanish settlements of the islands
column45: reside Sangleys
column46: who have come from Great China
column47: besides the merchants. They have appointed settlements and are engaged in various trades
column48: and go to the islands for their livelihood. Some possess their pariáns and shops. Some engage in fishing and farming among the natives
column49: throughout the country; and go from one island to another to trade
column50: in large or small champans. [424]The annual vessels from Great China bring these Sangleys in great numbers
column51: especially to the city of Manila
column52: for the sake of the profits that are gained from their fares. As there is a superabundance of population in China
column53: and the wages and profits there are little
column54: they regard as of importance whatever they get in the Filipinas.Very great annoyances result from this; for
column55: not only can there be little security to the country with so many infidels
column56: but the Sangleys are a wicked and vicious race. Through intercourse and communication with them
column57: the natives improve little in Christianity and morals. And since they come in such numbers and are so great eaters
column58: they raise the price of provisions
column59: and consume them.It is true that the city could not be maintained or preserved without these Sangleys; for they are the mechanics in all trades
column60: and are excellent workmen and work for suitable prices. But a less number of them would suffice for this
column61: and would avoid the inconvenience of so many people as are usually in Manila when the ships arrive--to say nothing of the many Chinese who go about among the islands
column62: under pretext of trading with the natives
column63: and there commit innumerable crimes and offenses. At the least
column64: they explore all the country
column65: the rivers
column66: creeks
column67: and ports
column68: and know them better than the Spaniards do; and they will be of great harm and injury in case of any revolt or hostile invasion of the islands.In order to remedy all the above
column69: it was ordered that the vessels should not bring so many people of this kind
column70: under penalties that are executed; that
column71: when the vessels return to China
column72: they take these Sangleys back with them; that only a convenient number of merchants remain in Manila
column73: in the Parián
column74: and the mechanics of all necessary trades; and that these must have written license
column75: under severe penalties. In the execution of this
column76: an auditor of the Audiencia is engaged by special commission every year
column77: together with some assistants. On petition of the city cabildo
column78: he usually allows as many Sangleys to remain as are necessary for the service of all trades and occupations. The rest are embarked and compelled to return in the vessels going to China
column79: and a great deal of force and violence [425] is necessary to accomplish it.

column1: Those merchants and artisans who remained in Manila before the revolt of the year six hundred and three had settled the Parián and its shops. The Parián is a large enclosed alcaicería of many streets
column2: at some distance from the city walls. It is near the river
column3: and its location is called San Graviel. There they have their own governor
column4: who has his tribunal and prison
column5: and his assistants; these administer justice to them
column6: and watch them day and night
column7: so that they may live in security
column8: and not commit disorders.Those who cannot find room in this Parián live opposite
column9: on the other side of the river
column10: where Tondo is
column11: in two settlements called Baybay and Minondoc. They are in charge of the alcalde-mayor of Tondo
column12: and under the ministry of the religious of St. Dominic
column13: who labor for their conversion
column14: and for that purpose have learned the Chinese language.The Dominicans have two monasteries with the requisite assistants
column15: and a good hospital for the treatment of Sangleys. In a district kept separate from the infidels
column16: they have a settlement of baptized Sangleys
column17: with their wives
column18: households
column19: and families
column20: numbering five hundred inhabitants; and the religious are continually baptizing others and settling them in that village. But few of them turn out well
column21: for they are a vile and restless race
column22: with many vices and bad customs. Their having become Christians is not through the desire or wish for salvation
column23: but for the temporal conveniences that they have there
column24: and because some are unable to return to China because of debts incurred and crimes committed there.Each and all
column25: both Christians and infidels
column26: go unarmed and in their national garb. This consists of long garments with wide sleeves
column27: made of blue cangan (but white for mourning
column28: while the chief men wear them of black and colored silks); wide drawers of the same material; half hose of felt; very broad shoes
column29: according to their fashion
column30: made of blue silk embroidered with braid--with several soles
column31: well-sewed--and of other stuffs. Their hair is long and very black
column32: and they take good care of it. They do it up on the head in a high knot
column33: [426] under a very close-fitting hood or coif of horsehair
column34: which reaches to the middle of the forehead. They wear above all a high round cap made of the same horsehair
column35: in different fashions
column36: by which their different occupations
column37: and each man's rank
column38: are distinguished. The Christians differ only in that they cut their hair short
column39: and wear hats
column40: as do the Spaniards.They are a light-complexioned people and tall of body. They have scant beards
column41: are very stout-limbed
column42: and of great strength. They are excellent workmen
column43: and skilful in all arts and trades. They are phlegmatic
column44: of little courage
column45: treacherous and cruel when opportunity offers
column46: and very covetous. They are heavy eaters of all kinds of meat
column47: fish
column48: and fruits; but they drink sparingly
column49: and then of hot beverages.They have a governor of their own race
column50: a Christian
column51: who has his officials and assistants. He hears their cases in affairs of justice
column52: in their domestic and business affairs. Appeals from him go to the alcalde-mayor of Tondo or of the Parián
column53: and from all these to the Audiencia
column54: which also gives especial attention to this nation and whatever pertains to it.No Sangley can live or own a house outside these settlements of the Parián
column55: and of Baybay and Minondoc. Native settlements are not allowed in Sangley settlements
column56: or even near them. No Sangley can go among the islands
column57: or as much as two leguas from the city
column58: without special permission. Much less can he remain in the city at night
column59: after the gates are shut
column60: under penalty of death.There are generally some Japanese
column61: both Christian and infidel
column62: in Manila. These are left by the vessels from Japon
column63: although they are not so numerous as the Chinese. They have their special settlement and location outside the city
column64: between the Sangley Parián and the suburb of Laguio
column65: near the monastery of La Candelaria. There they are directed by discalced religious of St. Francis
column66: by means of interpreters whom the fathers keep for that purpose. They are a spirited race
column67: of good disposition
column68: and brave. They wear their own costume
column69: namely
column70: kimonos of colored silks and cotton
column71: reaching half way down the leg
column72: and open in front; wide
column73: short drawers; close-fitting half-boots of leather
column74: [427] and shoes like sandals
column75: with the soles of well-woven straw. They go bare-headed
column76: and shave the top of the head as far back as the crown. Their back hair is long
column77: and fastened upon the skull in a graceful knot. They carry their catans
column78: large and small
column79: in the belt. They have scant beards
column80: and are a race of noble bearing and behavior. They employ many ceremonies and courtesies
column81: and attach much importance to honor and social standing. They are resolute in any necessity or danger.

column1: Those who become Christians prove very good
column2: and are very devout and observant in their religion; for only the desire for salvation incites them to adopt our religion
column3: so that there are many Christians in Japon. Accordingly they return freely
column4: and without opposition
column5: to their own country. At most there are about five hundred Japanese of this nation in Manila
column6: for they do not go to other parts of the islands
column7: and such is their disposition that they return to Japon
column8: and do not tarry in the islands; consequently very few of them usually remain in the islands. They are treated very cordially
column9: as they are a race that demand good treatment
column10: and it is advisable to do so for the friendly relations between the islands and Japon. [428]Few people come from the other nations--Sian
column11: Camboja
column12: Borneo
column13: Patan
column14: and other islands--outside our government; and they immediately return in their vessels. Consequently
column15: there is nothing special to be said of them
column16: except that care is exercised in receiving and despatching them well
column17: and seeing that they return quickly to their own countries.Since I have told
column18: in the short time at my disposal
column19: the characteristics of the Filipinas Islands
column20: and their customs and practices
column21: it will not be inappropriate to discuss the navigation to them since it is made thither from Nueva España; the return voyage
column22: which is not short
column23: or without great dangers and hardships; and that made in the eastern direction.When the islands were conquered in the year of one thousand five hundred and seventy-four [sic; sc. 1564]
column24: the Spanish fleet sailed under command of the adelantado Miguel Lopez de Legaspi
column25: from Puerto de la Navidad [429] situated in the South Sea
column26: on the coast of Nueva España
column27: in the province and district of Xalisco and Galicia
column28: where resides the royal Audiencia of Guadalajara. A few later voyages were made also from the same port
column29: until the point for the sending of these vessels was removed
column30: for better and greater convenience
column31: to the port of Acapulco
column32: located farther south on the same coast
column33: in sixteen and one-half degrees of latitude; it is eighty leguas from Mexico
column34: and in its district. It is an excellent port
column35: sheltered from all weather; and has a good entrance and good anchorages. Its vicinity is advantageous
column36: being better provisioned and more populous than that of La Navidad. There a large Spanish colony has been established
column37: with its alcalde-mayor
column38: and royal officials who have charge of his Majesty's treasury; and these attend to the despatch of the vessels.The vessels that sail to the Filipinas
column39: as they are despatched annually on his Majesty's account
column40: must necessarily leave in the certain season of the brisas
column41: which begin in the month of November and last until the end of March. This navigation should not be made at any other season
column42: for from June the vendavals blow
column43: and they are contrary to the voyage.As a rule
column44: these ships sail and are despatched at the end of February
column45: or at the latest by the twentieth of March. They sail west toward the islands of Las Velas
column46: [430] otherwise called the Ladrones. The island of Guan
column47: one of them
column48: lies in thirteen degrees of latitude. Inasmuch as the vessels on leaving Acapulco are wont sometimes to encounter calms
column49: they sail south from sixteen and one-half degrees
column50: in which the port is situated
column51: until they strike the brisas
column52: which is generally at ten or eleven degrees. By this route they sail continually before the wind
column53: and without changing the sails
column54: with fresh and fair brisas
column55: and in other moderate weather
column56: for one thousand eight hundred leguas
column57: without sighting any mainland or island. Then leaving to the south the Barbudos and other islands
column58: and advancing gradually to a latitude of thirteen degrees
column59: they sail until they sight the island of Guan; and above it
column60: in fourteen degrees
